characters: TRAPPED DOORS AT BOTTOM OF FUNNEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A white car sits in the yard of the farmhouse. On the door, a decal: "CAPETOWN SANITORIUM." Two men dressed in the white uniforms of the sanitorium exit the farm- house; one gently guiding a rather frail, troubled woman toward the car; the other totes her suitcase. The V.O. of a young man narrates:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There comes a time in everyone's life when they discover that the only person you can truly depend on is yourself. That the only real power anyone has to get anything done is the power of one. With any luck you can make it through a lot of years before you ever have to face the reality of that fact. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a luxury I never had. I discovered it the year my mother had her nervous breakdown. One attendant holds the rear door of the car open for the woman. Before entering, she turns one last time toward the farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young BOY looking one part scared, one part sad, and one part lost stares back at her, his hand held by a large, amiable black woman with tears rolling down her round cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was all of six.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The woman enters the car. The car drives off down the road. The Boy watches it disappear behind a plume of swirling dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father died before I was born, and even though I was raised by my Zulu nanny, with my mother, depending on her health, in nominal attendance, it was decided, with her departure, that I, too, would depart... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... for boarding school. The dust the Boy has been watching reverses itself. An unseen vehicle comes up the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before I could be sent out into the world one very serious matter had to be dealt with. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a chronic bedwetter. Since my nanny was the one responsible for my well-being, she did what any responsible Zulu mother would do. She called on the greatest medicine man of her tribe -- Inkosi Inkosikazi. Out of the dust a large black Buick ROADMASTER ROARS up the road and into the yard, scattering chickens and geese, stopping in front of the wide-eyed six-year-old and his tremulous nanny. A huge Zulu jumps out of the front passenger seat and opens the rear door. A moment passes, and then two splayed, cracked feet descend from the car and settle into the dust. INKOSI INKOSIKAZI, 100 years old, small, black, wizened, hair and beard whiter than cotton, a leopard skin draped over his shoulders, a beaded fly switch in one hand, a trussed chicken in the other, exits the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire burns bright in the black African night. The Boy sits holding the chicken, close by the fire, while Inkosi Inkosikazi shuffles around him, drawing a circle in the dust with a stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Legend had it that Inkosi Inkosikazi was the last son of the great Zulu king, Dingaan, who fought both the Boers and the British to a standstill nearly 100 years before, and the night Inkosi Inkosikazi was conceived stars fell from the sky until the sun rose. The circle    complete, the old man sits down opposite th Boy. From     a leather pouch he produces several bones. throws the    bones on the ground and studies them for a moment. He     begins to wave the fly switch back and for in front of    the Boy's eyes, chanting low, softly. The Boy's eyes    grow heavy; his lids droop.

dialogues.speaker: DREAM
dialogues.text: The Boy and the old man are standing above a great waterfall. In the swirling pool far below are ten stepping stones linking one bank to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The medicine man instructed me to jump off the falls and climb along the ten stepping stones, counting as I went until I reached dry land. The Boy jumps, cascading down the   falls and into the po below.  He clambers up the first   rock. It is slippery. He falls off and climbs back on,   buffeted by the sprayi water.  He makes his way stone by   stone toward the othe side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even though it was only a dream, I felt as if my struggle to reach dry land was terrifyingly real. The water was like ice, bone- chilling, cold, and as I made my way from one stone to the next I could feel my strength desert me. The progress from one step to the next gets progressively harder as the Boy keeps slipping into the swirling water, coughing and sputtering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was three rocks in when I ran out of gas. I couldn't pull myself any further. No matter how hard I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tried, the current tried harder. I felt myself going under for the last time. The Boy's grip slips off the rock.   He starts to go under.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire has gone out. The Boy is still sitting in the circle, the chicken still in his lap. His eyes snap open. The first thing he sees is Inkosi Inkosikazi sitting across from him with a big smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inkosi Inkosikazi enters the Buick. The Boy and his smiling nanny watch. They Boy still holds the chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inkosi Inkosikazi said the spirit of the great Zulu warriors lived in me. He told me that whenever trouble arose I should return to the waterfall and keep stepping across the rocks until the trouble passed. He said three rocks were enough to conquer my problem with the night water; that I was very brave. He said I was a man for all Africa, bound to her by my spirit, bound by my dreams. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he let me keep the chicken. The Boy and his nanny watch the car go off in a cloud of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy sits on a train looking out the window at the veldt and the wildlife moving across in the distance. A sack on his lap moves. The chicken's head pops out. The Boy gives him some kernels of corn and scratches behind his scraggly comb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although I was bound by spirit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and dream to Africa, I was bound by heritage and language to the birthplace of my grandparents -- England -- a country I had never seen, but one that was to cause me eminently more problems than bedwetting ever did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motorcar driving along the road to the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school I   was sent to was attended and   staffed entirely by Afrikaaners,   the oldest of the two white tribes   of Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The six-year-old walks timorously through the halls, filled with bigger boys -- brash, noisy, hostile. They only speak the "Taal" -- Afrikaans. Over and over they jostle or verbally deride the six-year-old, knocking his books down so that when he bends to pick them up he is kicked in the butt. Or pulling his shirt out from under his jacket and making it hard to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke only English. The hated tongue. The language of the enemy who had usurped power and stolen the country through political chicanery and military brutality. A mob of boys, led by a big bully, JAAPIE BOTHA, runs the six-year-old through the bathroom and into the showers, fully clothed. He tries to run out. Jaapie Botha grabs him and throws him back in, holding him with one ham-fisted hand under the shower head and turning the shower on with the other. The six-year-old stands miserable as the stinging water pelts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the Boer War of 1896, 26,000 Boer women and children were herded into detainment camps by the British, where they died like flies from dysentery,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: malaria and black water fever. And it seemed I was destined to shoulder the responsibility for each and every one of those deaths. The six-year-old in his first soccer game receives the ball. He tries to move  upfield, but he is kicked and pushed, the ball taken from him. He gets up gamely to follow the chase, only to be flattened, blindsided by Jaapie Botha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no one made this more evident to me than Jaapie Botha, a wheat farmer's son from the Transvaal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The six-year-old, asleep, his chicken perched alertly atop the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only time I was at peace was when I slept. Inkosi Inkosikazi's chicken proved to be, like his previous owner, a salvation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy builds a small shelter for the CHICKEN, who CLUCKS and forages contentedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the day he would live outside the dorm, happily scarfing down bugs and grubs, secure in a little house I built for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And at night he would hop through the window and, perching over my bed, squawking if any intruders came near.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several boys sneak up in the    dark. The CHICKEN begins to CHATTER. The six-year-old     wakes, a shoe in hand ready to throw. The shadows     scatter. The Boy gives th chicken a few grains of corn    and an affectionate scrat behind the ear, and goes back    to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was my best and only friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys and faculty running through the halls excitedly, showing newspapers with pictures of Hitler and Chamberlain on the front. Posters and slogans with swastikas are slapped up on walls. Some boys mimic "heiling" to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure in time a status quo would have been achieved between me and my schoolmates were it not for the cataclysmic events occurring in that faraway place none of us had ever seen. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two montjhs after I arrived at the school World War II broke out in Europe. Hitler had vowed to crush the British Empire. The Boers sharpened their swords in anticipation. The six-year-old comes back to his bed in the dorm to find a swastika carved into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The six-year-old sleeps fitfully. There is a MUFFLED SQUAWK. He wakes. A blanket is thrown over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy is dumped on the floor, the blanket removed. His eyes open in horror. The room is lit by torches. Shadows dance fearfully off two dozen boys with swastika armbands and leather pistol rigs without pistols strapped to their sides. In front of him on a platform Jaapie Botha stands, his shirtsleeves rolled to the shoulder,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as another student painfully tattoo-scars his arm with a swastika, using a knife and blue dye. Seeing the six- year-old, Jaapie turns his attention to him and addresses him in Afrikaans. JAAPIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God has sent Hitler to deliver us from the English bastards who stole our country and killed our people. Heil Hitler! The other boys chorus in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler! JAAPIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will swear a blood oath. When Hitler comes we'll rise up and kill the Verdomde Rooineks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blood oath!    A blood oath! Jaapie bends down and grabs the six-year-old by the shirt front, yanking him up. JAAPIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With your blood. Jaapie slaps the Boy across the mouth three times. Blood flows from his mouth and nose. Jaapie dips his finger in the blood and smears it across his new tattoo. He holds up his bloodied fingers. JAAPIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We swear allegiance to Adolf Hitler. Heil Hitler! ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We swear allegiance to Adolf Hitler. Heil Hitler! JAAPIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death to all Englishmen in South Africa. Heil Hitler! The chorus repeats. JAAPIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless the fatherland.    Heil Hitler! The voices come back to him stronger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler! Jaapie grabs the six-year-old again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what we have in store for you when Hitler comes, Rooinek. Hoy! He gives a command. The boys at the far end of the room part. The six-year-old's eyes open in terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 feet away Inkosi Inkosikazi's chicken, his chicken, is hung from a rafter upside down, haplessly flapping against his bonds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! But before he gets two steps towards the chicken he is gang-tackled and held. Jaapie picks up a sling and a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For crimes committed against the whole Boer people. I, Jaapie Botha, the judge and Uberfuhrer, sentence you and your Rooinek kaffir chicken to death. Heil Hiter.!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler! Jaapie starts to swing the sling around and around.     T six-year-old struggles to get free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler!   Heil Hitler! The SLING WHISTLES through the air, faster and faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Jaapie releases the stone. It flies true, catching the SQUAWKING, struggling CHICKEN flush in the chest. The flapping stops as blood soaks through feathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaapie flings his hand forward, victorious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler! The Boy takes the opportunity to break loose. He rushes Jaapie, whose arm is outstretched, putting him off balance. The Boy catches him low, driving his head into Jaapie's exposed stomach. Jaapie falls back and gets the knife used for his tattooing right in his ass. Jaapie Botha bellows like an enraged bull as he grabs futiley for the embedded blade. His cohorts laugh, thinking it tremendously funny, until Jaapie removes the knife and turns with it, dripping his own blood, his eyes murderous. The laughter dies. Jaapie's breath comes hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang him up! A few boys protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaapie!   No! But Botha is murderous, intent on revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang him! He waves the bloody knife in the air. Three boys grab the six-year-old and drag him to where the chicken is hanging. Two more boys throw a rope over the same rafter. Others bind the struggling boy, trussing his hands to his sides. JAAPIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will pay for the deaths of our grandfathers and grandmothers, our aunts and uncles. All Rooineks will pay and you will be first. Pull! The boys who tied the rope now yank it over the rafter. The six-year-old is hoisted up until he is eye-level with the chicken. JAAPIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the name of Adolf Hitler and the fatherland, I sentence you to die, Verdomde Rooinek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill him!   Kill him!   Kill him! Jaapie swings the sling overhead, faster and faster.

dialogues.speaker: SIX-YEAR-OLD
dialogues.text: He watches as Jaapie bears down. As Jaapie is about to let the rock fly the door to the room opens and two STAFF MEMBERS burst in, surprising in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this? The rock flies from the sling, but Jaapie's attention is diverted. His aim is off. The rock grazes the boy above the eye. He loses consciousness. The scene FADES TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince of Wales School, 1950. PK, 17     going on 18, wel built, intense, clear-eyed, handsome,    stands in front a seminar and continues reading to 10    students, honor students, Headmaster St. John's chosen    few. St. John, with the demeanor of an Oxford don and    a mane of snowy white hair that reaches his shoulders,    sits off to the side, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to after being unconscious for two days, the rock missing my eye by half an inch. After a week in hospital it was decided I'd be sent to my grandfather's house in the English town of Barberton, at least until passions at school cooled. Jaapie Botha was expelled; sent home to his family's farm in disgrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so the first recorded South African casualty of Hitler's insanity was not a Boer, nor a Rooinek, but a tatter-feathered, half-bald kaffir chicken. PK finishes. The end of class BELL RINGS. Offstage, other classrooms are exiting into the common hall, but no one in St. John's study moves. St. John takes his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: glasses off and wipes the lenses deliberately.   After a long moment he turns to face the class. ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very evocative, yes. Particularly the image of the chicken. Good choice there. St. John rises, lecturing. ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any ideology that needs to attack the thing that least threatens it is an ideology that will not outlive its own generation. Inclusion, gentlemen, not exclusion, is the key to survival. (beat) Something our new government should take heed of, eh? His eyes roam from face to face, fixing his point. ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next week we have Mr. Levy who will enlighten us on... MORRIE, a bright-eyed kinetic, speaks up. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sport and wager in Imperial Rome, sir. ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (facetious) Very apt, Mr. Levy. We look forward to the experience. (pause) All right. The boys bolt for the door.

dialogues.speaker: P.K.
dialogues.text: PK approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well-written. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've received notice from the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxford selection committee. You are to appear before them in three weeks. I assume you'll be reading a piece of your fiction as your presentational.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A word of caution. Contemporary to most of these fellows means the seventeenth century. Try and keep your theme, um, classical, if you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. I will. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will the scholarship be decided at the same time, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money's a different matter. Different committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, sir. St. John picks up a book and opens the pages. He begins to read. PK takes it as a cue for his dismissal. He goes to exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And P.K... PK turns at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. St. John returns to his book.    PK exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie waits in the now nearly-empty hall, taking some money from another boy and making notations in a black book. PK comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How we doing? Morrie consults the book. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You win and your dream comes true. You lose, we're back to bread and butter sandwiches till term's end. What'd he want? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My appointement before the Oxford committee came through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A snap. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a brain like you, maybe. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you'll read one of your pieces, they'll be begging you to attend. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But will they pay for the privilege? MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well let's bloody hope so. It'll be a lonely time without you there. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie Levy. Is that the voice of sentimentality I hear coming from you? MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sentimentality my ass. Practicality. Where am I going to find a sure thing like you to make book on at bloody Oxford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. He shoves Morrie playfully out the door and follows.

dialogues.speaker: PK AND MORRIE
dialogues.text: as they walk down the long   hall looking straight ahead. Sweat dapples PK's face.    Both boys are focused on double doors at the end of   the hall. There is the distant MUFFLED sound of a   CROWD CHEERING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear Sutcliffe screwed Bartlett's sister when he stayed with them over holidays?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard it from Bartlett's own lips. He's selling reservations for next holiday. A pound for one night; three pounds for four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You register?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For both of us. Took the whole holiday. The CHEERING crowd grows LOUDER the closer they get to the double doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You nervous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ! I'm about to have a calf. This bloody Boer gets lucky, we're in the poorhouse. They reach the double doors. Still in CLOSEUP, Morrie turns to face PK for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now remember. We're not here to exhibit our wares. We go in, we do the job, we get out. Right? PK is so focused his eyes seem to bore through the doors. He does not move his head a hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie and PK draw a deep breath. Together they push open the double doors. Together they stride into a floodlit, fully-packed sports arena and head down the fan-lined aisle to the raised boxing ring in the center. Schoolboys in their respective school blazers, Afrikaan and English, yell, whistle and clap. PK and Morrie, in FULL FRAME, reveal PK in a boxing robe with taped hands, and Morrie with towel and bucket. ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And at the end of six matches in all weight divisions, the score is Prince of Wales three victories, Helpmakeer three victories. The stands explode with cheers. ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now for the final bout to determine which school will win the Johannesburg 1950 public school boxing team championship. In this corner, weighing 140 pounds, standing 5'8", from the Helpmakeer School with a record of 13-0 on the year, Jannie Geildenhaus. A huge cheer goes up for JANNIE, muscular, bare-chested, as he dances and shadowboxes for the crowd. PK enters the ring. He stands, robe on, eyes intent on Jannie. When the noise subsides the Announcer continues. ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in this corner, representing the Prince of Wales School, the current Johannesburg Public School welterweight champion, also with a record of 13-0 on the year, also 140 pounds, Kid P.K. Now the English schoolboys cheer for their man, but PK does not respond. He barely moves. He raises an arm in bare acknowledgment. His attention stays focused across the ring on his shadowboxing opponent. PK watches Jannie dance closely when a low CHANTING begins from outside the stadium -- African, tribal, mystical harmonies of black voices building until the white voices inside the stadium are stunned to silence. The song carries beautifully in the night. For the first time PK's focus is broken, but not like the others in the audience, who haven't a clue as to what's happening. He has heard this before. This is familiar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for him. A distant knowing flickers in his eyes like a man who has heard the voice of fate whisper his name. Over and over, one phrase is indistinguishable -- the chorus of the song. "Ono  bi shobi ingelosi." The chanting stops as suddenly as it began. A moment passes before the crowd begins to buzz with the phenomenon. The Announcer attempts to bring everyone's attention back to the business at hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thank the native population for their spirited display of enthusiasm. But now, on to the main event. Fighters to center ring, please. PK, focused again, meets Jannie at the REFEREE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You both know the rules.     No butts, no elbows, no low    blows. First man to score three    knock downs wins. Let's have     a good clean fight. Good luck     to you. The fighters slap leather. PK turns back to his corner when his focus is broken dramatically by a face in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT ROW
dialogues.text: sit; one of them MARIA ELIZABETE MARAIS, 17, with honey- blonde hair and lapis-blue eyes, turns her head and engages PK's eyes and his heart. She quickly looks away. But a  connection has been made -- fire passed.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: goes back to his corner and takes off his robe.   Morrie stands, holding PK's mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First row, third from the left. Find out who she is. Morrie looks down at Maria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in a bloody war here, in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: case you forgot. Let's keep our mind on that, hey? He jams the mouthpiece into PK's mouth as the BELL RINGS. PK turns to an onslaught by Jannie, a real brawler. Jannie's big, overhand rights almost nail PK until he finds his footing and dances away. Jannie comes after him hard, his schoolmates bellowing encouragement. But PK's far superior boxing skills put Jannie at an immed- iate disadvantage. It is a classic battle of a boxer versus a fighter. PK's jabs keep Jannie at an arm's length, until he closes with a combination. Jannie, willing to take three punches to land one, absorbs PK's point scoring combinations and tries to land knockout punches. When he has had enough punishment he lunges into a clinch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blery Rooinek.     I'll kill you. PK pushes off as Jannie hammers at his kidneys. Backing up, PK repays the compliment with two quick jabs to the face. PK works Jannie, turning him left then right, working the angles, keeping him off balance while he racks up the points. Jannie goes left. As PK chases him that way his eyes fix on something out of the ring.

dialogues.speaker: REAR EXIT DOOR
dialogues.text: with a younger black companion of more average height, the only black faces in a crowd of 2,000 people.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Their presence distracts    PK for a split second, and in that split second Jannie    seizes the opportunity. He comes across with a big    right hand to PK's jaw. Jannie connects. PK goes down     hard. The crowd goes wild. Morrie leaps up and down    in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up!     Get up! But PK is seeing double.    He shakes his head, trying to clear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up!   Up!

dialogues.speaker: JANNIE
dialogues.text: dancing in his corner, sensing victory, the Ref over

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: him, counting.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: PK forces himself up.   The Ref checks him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Fight. Jannie comes rushing in, banging PK with a series of hard rights, but dropping his left each time he throws one. PK absorbs the punishment as best he can, backing up, dancing away. Jannie is all over him just as the BELL RINGS. Jannie goes back to his corner, triumphant. PK goes back to his and sits down with a blank ex- pression. Morrie goes to work on a small cut over his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you trying to do, bankrupt us? What happened? PK turns and looks at the two Africans at the rear door. Morrie's eyes follow him, tensing as he sees the two men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ! If they get caught in here they're dead. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, worry about it later. In case you haven't noticed, this Boer bastard is trying to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see the way he drops his left when he throws the right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? The BELL RINGS. PK and   Morrie trade a look. Jannie comes rushing over and  throws a big right. PK steps to his own right side and  pops Jannie right over his droppe left hand. He looks at   Morrie again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, God. Jannie comes after PK, paying for each big right he throws as PK finds his mark. PK plants one, then two, then three punches on Jannie's face. Finally, frus- trated, Jannie forsakes all pretense of boxing and tries to nail PK with wild, flailing blows. PK bobs and weaves and feints. Jannie's punches grow weary. PK begins to bear down, driving his man back with rapid-fire com- binations until he delivers the coup de grace, a left hook to the heart and a driving right uppercut. Jannie goes down in a heap. The crowd goes wild. The Referee counts him out. Jannie's seconds rush into the ring to lift their fallen fighter. Morrie also rushes in, followed by the Prince of Wales boxing team. They hoist PK up on their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA MARAIS
dialogues.text: rising from her seat, and leaving with the other girls. Their eyes meet. Her hint of a smile breaks his heart. She disappears in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: PK's eyes rise to the rear exit.   The tall African and his companion have vanished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boxing team and a number of their supporters are in raucous celebration. Morrie comes bouncing through the crowd, until he enters the empty dressing room in the rear, where PK is getting dressed. Morrie takes a wad of money out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go, pal. He hands PK the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the treasurer of this company. You hold it. Did you find out what I asked for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, listen, P.K. You know in this world there is no greater proponent of sins of the flesh than Morrie Levy. But  do yourself a favor on this one.  Take my advice. Pass. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the advice.    The information please. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who her father is? Professor Daniel Marais.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? He's the Nationalist Party's resident intellectual. The man is one of the architects of this damned system of -- what are they calling it? -- apartheid? He has about as much use for a Rooinek Englishman rutting after his daughter as the Queen does for balls, pardon my French. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her name and where do I find her? Morrie sighs. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria Elizabete Marais, Seniors Cottage, Room 22, Devilliers School. They don't call it 'Fortress Virgin' for nothing. You'll never get in. PK slips his school blazer on. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to take book on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already have.    Three-to-one says you don't. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you bet? MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took a big position you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK smiles at his friend and starts to leave.    Morrie stuffs some banknotes in his breast pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case you have to bail yourself out. PK boxes him around playfully and skips out, running the gauntlet of the celebration outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, "Fortress Virgin." Surrounded by a high stone wall, the school's gothic towers loom medieval in the African moonlight. A security guard mans the front gate. PK takes a route through shadows and shrubs, searching for a way in. He finds one in a tree whose massive limbs reach over the wall. In a flash PK is up the tree and over the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK makes his way through the darkened campus. A few stu- dents and some staff are about. PK hugs the shadows as best he can. PK passes a statue dominating the quad -- a Boer family from the last century; the man looking for- ward, his gun braced for action; the women and children at his shoulder, brave, resolute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK comes up to the cottage where a few girls can be seen through the windows studying at lamplit desks or readying for bed. Other rooms are already dark. PK slips inside the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK moves along the hall looking for room 22. He is about to turn a corner when TWO GIRLS chattering in Afrikaans come down a staircase. PK backs into a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: darkened room to his left. The girls appear        in rob with towels and toiletries and step into the       same r One flicks on the light to reveal the shower       room - separate cubicle stalls. Still chattering,        the gir disrobe.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: pressed hard against the inside wall of a stall with a clear view of the proceedings. He holds his breath as one of the girls heads towards his stall. Her girl- friend cautions her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are always cold.     Use this one. The girl turns away to another stall just in time. The SHOWERS START. PK allows himself to breathe again. He exits quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria Marais sits at her      desk in a nightgown,  worki a paper, when there is a      KNOCK on the door.   With h mind still on her work,      she opens the door.   Her ey wide with shock when she      sees PK. He puts a   cautio finger to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I come in? Maria, frozen with surprise, steps back.       PK enters, gently closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to scare you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be here. She speaks in Afrikaan-accented English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know how else to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could be expelled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls don't usually come to boxing matches. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We went on a dare. Please. PK ignores her anxiety. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was... (beat) ... exciting.    You were very good. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Afrikaans) Thank you. I'm glad I impressed you. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) You speak the Taal. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll speak Zulu if it'll help me see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need my father's permission. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it hard to get? MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard for an Afrikaaner boy. Impossible for an English one. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about your permission?    Do I have that? Maria blushes. All of a sudden there is a KNOCK on the door. Maria starts. PK moves quickly behind the door as it opens to TWO GIRLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIRL #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're having coffee upstairs. Want to come? MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to finish this paper. GIRL #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come when you're finished.     We'll be up late. They close the door.    Maria reinforces it with her body

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please go. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't answer my question. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are plenty of English girls. What makes me so important? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way I felt when I saw you. He is so direct she can only blush deeper.       Her resp is indirect but affirmative. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father will insist on meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait. O.S., the outside door to the dorm opens.        A matron voice calls out. MATRON (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights out, ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now please. PK opens her window and starts to climb out. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Afrikaans) Good night, Maria Marais. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in English) Good night, PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember telling you my name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't remember telling you mine. PK smiles back at her. He drops to the ground. Maria closes the window and watches him scoot across the campus until he is swallowed by the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ample house. PAN ACROSS a gallery of oil paintings depicting great moments in Boer history -- the Great Trek an endless progression of oxcarts heading north, the Battle of Blood River against the Zulu armies, the hang- ing of Boer farmers by British regulars. Women and children herded into a detention camp as their farms burn in the background. Boer kommandos sniping at a British column on the veldt. PAN FROM the pictures TO photographs, sepia-toned, his- torical, and DR. DANIEL MARAIS and PK, strolling past the pictures. Marais points to a photo of a young Boer, turn of the century, posed stiffly with a rifle in the slouche hat of a Boer kommando.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan Piet Marais. My uncle. At 22 he led a kommando for three years before your people caught him and hung him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I consider myself an African, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As do I. As do the Zulu, the Xhosa, the Pongo, the Ndebele. We're all Africans. But all from separate tribes, ay?

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: Unfortunately.

dialogues.speaker: MARAIS
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: Because it's the whole tribal idea that creates our problems here in South Africa.

dialogues.speaker: MARAIS
dialogues.text: The problems of South Africa, my boy, do not come from tribalism. They come from counter-tribalism. From people insisting that natural laws which have been in place and operating since God's creation, should be tampered with. Does the gazelle sleep with the lion? Does the rhino graze with the mouse? The separation of things is not coincidental. Do you think a Zulu wants to see his culture, his sense of identity, replaced by someone else's anymore than I do?

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: No, sir. But I don't think he wants being a Zulu to mean he is denied the same rights as everyone else has.

dialogues.speaker: MARAIS
dialogues.text: Which is why civilization is defined by the ability to live under the rule of law. Laws define rights.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: But do they define justice?

dialogues.speaker: MARAIS
dialogues.text: Ah. Justice. The banner behind which the English marched as they gobbled up a quarter of the world? Justice, my boy, is only relative to who's in charge.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: And how long they stay in charge is only relative to how well they dispense that justice... (beat) ... with all due respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marais fixes PK with a stare.   PK's eyes meet his evenly unwavering. Maria enters. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa, would you like coffee in the library or the parlor? MARAIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasant) The library, mein leib. Maria smiles at PK and exits.   He leads PK towards the library. MARAIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't figure out if you're brave or foolish. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is that, sir? MARAIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come here to ask for permission to see my daughter. Correct? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. MARAIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And knowing  who I am, what I stand for, do you  think this sort of discussion  is going to put that request in  a favorable light? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought a man of your intellectual reputation wouldn't want his daughter seeing someone who didn't think. MARAIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me give you some advice then. You're right. I admire a keen mind.  But intellectual reputation or not, I am first a Marais, a member of the Volk. MARAIS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you're trying to impress a member of the Volk with your intellect, don't do it espousing liberal ideas picked up in an English private school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These ideas I picked up somewhere else. Marais opens the library door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt from an expert on race relations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, sir, from an expert on cactus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brilliant African sun beats down on the veldt below. On the rock, a seven-year-old PK sits looking somewhat sadly over the landscape. A long shadow covers him. The CLICK of a CAMERA is heard. PK turns, shielding his eyes with his hand against the glare of the sun to a tall, white-haired figure, shirtless, in hiking boots and kneesocks, holding a box camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja. Perfect.    You will excuse me, please. DOC, speaking in German-accented English, moves off from the sun's glare down to PK's level. On his back is a knapsack with a cactus sticking out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This I do not normally without permission do, ja? But to catch the expression. After all, it is the expression that is important. Ja? Without the expression the human being is just a lump of meat. You have some problems, I think. I am Professor Karl von Vollensteen. Doc clicks his heels together and bows his head slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm P.K. He holds out his hand.   Doc takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a young person with such an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: old expression. I think we can be friends. Ja? Eighteen-year-old PK narrates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was how I met Doc, as he insisted I call him. A chance meeting between a directionless seven-year-old boy and an old German professor out collecting cacti on the African bush veldt. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So began my education. Doc and PK walk the veldt across craggy mountain trails, down dry river beds, through the jungle, always collectin cacti and aloe samples, Doc always talking, always explaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc believed the brain had two functions and that the South African public school system unfortunately dealt with only one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brain, P.K., has two functions. It is the best reference library ever, which is a good thing to have. Ja? But also from it comes original thought. In school you will get all filled up with the facts. Here your brain will learn where to look, how to look, how to think. And then you will have for yourself all the brains that have ever been. Doc and PK sit high up. PK watches the endless animal migration below while Doc points things out across the landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc knew everything. He had a love of learning. But his real passion was centered around two things -- music and cacti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK and Doc walk up a steep road toward Doc's house which sits on top of the hill, both carrying cacti-filled

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: packs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until he was fifty, Doc had a successful career as a concert pianist all over Europe. On his fiftieth birthday he gave it all up and moved to South Africa. From that point on it was all cactus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Doc's simple, whitewashed cottage is a magnif- icent cactus and aloe garden filled with the samples Doc has collected for years. PK and Doc plant another specimen. Doc photographs it. PK records its genus in a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every specimen Doc found would be carefully photographed and catalogued.

dialogues.speaker: SUNSET
dialogues.text: Doc an PK walk through the cactus garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If God would choose a plant to represent Him, I think He would choose of all plants the cactus. This one plant has all the blessings He tried but failed to give man. It is true. Look. The cactus is humble but not submissive. It grows where no other plant will grow. The sun bakes its back, the wind rips it from cliffs, or drowns it in the dry desert sand. Not a complaint. In good times or bad it will still flower. It protects itself from danger. Doc touches a cactus needle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it harms no other plant.   It

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: has patience and solitude and modesty. In Mexico there is a cactus that blooms once in a hundred years and then only at night. That is saintliness of the highest order I think. Ja? From cactus comes medicine to heal the wounds of men and little buttons if you eat one you can touch the face of God or stare into the mouth of hell. It is the plant of patience, solitude, love, and madness. Modesty, beauty. Toughness and gentleness. Of all the plants I think it is closest to God. Ja?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc was a hard man to disagree with. So when he decided I must spend as much time with him to remedy the flaw in my educational environment I didn't argue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shabbily-genteel, Doc sits in his Sunday best, a cup of tea on his lips, talking in earnest to PK's pipe- puffing, also shabbily-genteel grandfather as PK looks on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appealing to my grandfather's stoic belief in the primacy of European culture in all its forms, Doc offered to instruct me in piano in return for my helping him locate and gather his precious cacti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc and PK practice on a beautiful Steinway, so grandly out of place in Doc's simple abode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a student of music I was never more than adequate, something I suspect Doc knew from the start. It is the love of music that is most important, he would tell me, and I would believe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc and PK wander through the jungle looking for flora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything fits, P.K. Nothing is unexplained. Nature is one big chain reaction. Everything depends on everything else. From the smallest to the biggest. Always in life an idea starts small like a tree. Doc shows PK a small tree with an even smaller vine attached to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This tree can grow so high it can touch the face of the sky. But this little vine can choke it and keep it small. Most people are like these vines. Afraid of new ideas. Afraid to let things grow. Doc rips the vine away from the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always listen to yourself. Follow your own idea. If you are wrong, so what? You learn something. And with learning you grow stronger. And if you are right at the beginning? An even bigger bonus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc and PK move alongside the great herds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I roamed the kloofs and ridges, the dry riverbeds and jungle floors with Doc for over a year, learning more than I realize even today. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also played a lot more 'God Save the King' due to my new musical celebrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACK THROUGH Barberton, a small town on the low veldt, in all its colonial backwater splendor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barberton was a very proper English town with a proper square, a wide main street, and the colonials' overblown patriotism for a homeland most people had never seen, hanging in the air like fine dust. Not quite seen, but there nonetheless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK plays "God Save the King" on the stage. The town's population stands -- the men, stoic; the women, dewey- eyed, at patriotic attention. Some people file out -- the men in officers' uniforms of the South African penal system and their wives -- Boers. They exit to the dagger stares and some undertoned hissing and booing from Her Majesty's loyal subjects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only Afrikaaners to live in Barberton were sent there to work at the government prison, just outside town. Germany had covertly supported the Boers in their two unsuccessful wars against British rule, supplying food and medical supplies as well as ample stocks of ammunition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Germany was an old friend, a trusted friend. And in a country where a handshake is a friendship and a friendship a bond for life, as the war in Europe grew fiercer tensions in Barberton heated up. Suspicion was afoot. Spies were everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc and PK walk toward the cottage.   Doc reads PK's report card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grammar: satisfactory. Science: satisfactory. Mathetmatics: satisfactory. He looks down at PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.K., if there is one thing I know you to be that is a lot more than just satisfactory. Ja?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't want to be known as a brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think gets beaten up on all the time in school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boy, to be smart is not a sin. But to be smart and not use it, that is sin number one. And as for getting beat up on, use your brain to figure out how not to be. He hands PK the report card, his displeasure obvious. As they crest the hill the cottage comes INTO VIEW along with a parked Army car and two armed soldiers leaning against it. Seeing Doc and PK, the soldiers smarten up, raising their rifles and advancing. Doc's face grows pale, his lips tight.   PK pulls close t him for support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again it begins. The stupidity. Do not be frightened. Doc puts na arm around PK's shoulder, drawing him close, comforting him. One of the soldiers pulls a pair of handcuffs out of his pocket as he advances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car pulls up. Doc, in shackles, is escorted from the car. PK exits after him. Two guards lead Doc toward the doorway to the prison, a square in the looming gates. Doc walks, his head held high. PK walks alongside holding his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl von Vollensteen, for the failure to register as an alien during times of war in accordance with His Majesty's government orders to do so, you are hereby sentenced to be confined at Barberton prison for the duration of the war with Germany. At the door a guard touches PK's   shoulder, holding him back. The door opens. Doc goes     through. Just before the door closes he looks back at   PK one last time. The door slams shut. PK, with tears    streaming down his cheeks, is left outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie lies in bed, asleep.   PK sits up at his desk, writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And again I was alone with nothing to depend on to see me through except the power of one. PK puts down his pen and sits, regarding the pages. He raises his eyes to a photo on the desk of a boy on a rock. PK smiles at hidden memories, caps his fountain pen, turns off the light. The room is pitched into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seedy side of town. PK carrying a gym bag and Morrie looking a bit out of place in their school blazers come striding up the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, even if the scholarship doesn't come through, my old man said he'd lend you the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. All right. We'll call it the 'Levy Carpet Emporium Scholarship for Poor but Proud Christian Gentlemen.' How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell your father I appreciate the offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I hate people who can't be bought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.    Personality disorder. PK nods in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Undoubtedly. The boys come to their destination marked by a rickety, faded sign: "GOLDMAN'S GYM." Excitement shines in PK's eyes. He bounds up the narrow flight of stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie and PK rush up the stairs, stop at the landing, and collect themselves before opening the door to the gym. They take a breath and enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A down and dirty boxing gym, humming with the rhythm of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: men training. Sweat and smoke fill the air along with the faint scent of blood. Fighters, both black and white, train with each other. Morrie is amazed. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do they get away with this? But PK has his mind on other things. His eyes fix on an OLD MAN across the room standing by ringside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, he's old. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's the best.    C'mon. PK leads Morrie across the gym. PK passes an African fighter. He stops training when he sees PK. He turns to another African fighter, glancing at PK. One by one the blacks in the gym stop training to look at PK. PK and Morrie approach the rheumy Old Man yelling at the two fighters in the ring above him in a thick Polish- Jewish accent. SOLLY (OLD MAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. God gave you two hands so you can knock a man out from either side. Left-right. He moves his creaky body back and forth to demonstrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Goldman? Solly turns to the boys. A look of bemusement comes over his face when he sees their blazers. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?    You boys lost? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the one who called you yesterday. From the Prince of Wales School?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, yeah.     The champeen. Right? PK (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who are you? MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The champeen's manager. Solly rolls his eyes to heaven. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oy gevalt. (beat) You know you train here it's not like those nice school fights you're used to. Three knockdowns you win. Just then, as if to underscore his point, one of the fighters in the ring gets caught witha solid shot to the jaw. He hits the canvas inches from where they are standing. Solly, PK and Morrie all look at him, and then at each other. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it cost for you to train him? SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For my personal attentinons, Mr. Manager? Fifty pounds a month. For one of them... (points to the other men working with fighters)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... less. Morrie pulls out a wad of money and proffers it to Solly. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's for six months in advance. Three hundred pounds. Solly pushes the money back. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months? I don't know your boy'll last six minutes. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll last. Solly notices that every black fighter in the gym has stopped working and is staring at PK. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you staring? Punch, don't stare. C'mon. Work or you're out. The blacks go back to work. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That your gear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go change in the back. We'll see if you couldn't find a better use for all that money. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. PK heads towards the rear.      Solly turns to Morrie. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's he want to do this, a nice- looking schoolboy? MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to be welterweight champ of the world. Solly breaks up laughing. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure, sure. And I'd like to be twenty-five again. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like to make book on it? SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking) You giving odds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You name them. Solly gives him a long look. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You both meshugah. Solly walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK is in the ring getting ready to spar with a well-built opponent. Morrie stands at ringside with Solly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just start out nice and easy now. He hits the bell. The fighters circle. PK's opponent starts punching, jabbing, probing. After two feints he comes after PK in earnest. PK steps left and peppers him with three quick blows to the face. Solly's interest is suddenly piqued. Again the fighters circle. Again the opponent sets up with jabs and again he attacks. This time PK dodges, hits him hard and spins him around, hitting him twice more. A smile appears on Solly's face. The opponent, angered now, gets more aggressive. PK keeps bobbing and weaving, sticking and slipping punches. The opponent unloads, banging away at PK with everything he has. PK backs up two steps, then shifts positions. The opponent's momentum carries him into the ropes. As he comes off the ropes PK throws him an eight-punch combination, demolishing his opponent. PK steps back. The opponent sags. Solly hits the bell, clearly excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never I seen someone so young throw an eight-punch combination. Where did you learn such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In prison, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You trying to be a comedian and a boxer? Mr. Manager, come to my office. We'll talk terms. You, get showered, and see me after. We'll talk training. Solly and Morrie head off toward Solly's office. PK watches them go, a small victorious smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven-year-old PK stands at the gate holding a bucket, waiting to be let in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK sits on a bench in the hall. Black prisoners are marched by, guarded closely. At PK's feet is the metal bucket.  The door to Kommandant Von Zyl's office opens. A guard summons PK. PK rises, takes his bucket and enters the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The KOMMANDANT, a brusque man with a salt-and-pepper brush cut sits behind his big desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you are PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Kommandant Von Zyl. The professor has requested you to be his visitor so you can continue your studies on piano and he can continue with his studies on cactus. This is the first specimen? He alludes to the bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.   Kalanchoe Thrysiflora. He holds the bucket up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small cactus resting on some tobacco leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The professor taught you this, ja? Of course to your English town he is a prisoner, a criminal. To us who respect such learning and culture, he is an honored guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands PK a pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This pass is good for any time, any day. Would you like to see him now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come.   I will take you myself. Von Zyl rises and opens the door for PK.    They exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK and Von Zyl walk together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have cleared a little plot behind the cellblock for the cactus. And tomorrow we have the professor's piano moved here. There is not another instrument like it in the territory. Maybe one day the two of you can give a concert for us, hey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Just then the sound of GRUNTING and THWACKING fills the air. PK passes a room set up as a boxing gym. Through a crack in the door he sees a dozen boys being coached by some guards. Some guards are also being coached by a second man. A third man, LIEUTENANT SMIT, oversees the whole training session. PK watches, mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like to box?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to learn, meneer. Are the boys prisoners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. The sons of the guards. See that one there? (points to a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: little pudge boy flailing away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my son, Danie. It's a club. Lieutenant Smit. Smit comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have room for one more on the squad? Smit looks down at PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a little small, Kommandant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll build him up then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.   But I really don't have anyone  to spare to teach him right now.   You know, with the tournament  coming up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be someone. Smit looks around the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crumpled, old BLACK MAN, a lifer with broken, bandied legs and a fighter's flattened face, wiping the floor, picking up used towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piet. GEEL PIET comes shuffling over, properly submissive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You teach this boy basics, and you teach him good or I knock your black head flat, you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I teach him best I know, baas. SMIT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We train every day. First thing in the morning. Miss two trainings, you're gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, meneer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come tomorrow.     See this old kaffir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, meneer.     Thank you, meneer. VON ZYL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, a word? The two men step off to the side. GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, little baas. Little can beat big any day. First with the head, then with the heart. Little defeat big when little is smart. You can remember that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. Don't never call me sir. 'Specially in front of the guards. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I call you? GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piet.   Geel Piet. COACH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaffir.   Towels. Geel Piet assumes his submissive posture again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, baas.    Coming, baas. He winks at PK and shuffles off.     A BELL SOUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bell at the top of a strongman's game sounds. A big Boer farmer, mallet in hand, roars in triumph, swinging the mallet again and ringing the bell again.

dialogues.speaker: PK AND MARIA
dialogues.text: walking through the carnival, munching popcorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took a big chance talking to my father the way you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. Going in I was behind on points with him. I'm English. I attend a politically suspect school. I'm a boxer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He likes boxers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All men like boxers. But not for their daughters. So I had to find some way to make an impression. They get on line for the Ferris wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have picked a more agreeable topic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And made much less of an impression. Talk to someone about their passion. Even if they disagree they'll remember you. It was really the most logical strategy if you think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you spend hours thinking about how to deal with me, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what I think? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dangerous. Their turn comes to mount the Ferris wheel.         They into the seat and strap in. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was little we would go to my grandfather's farm in the high veldt for holiday. The Ferris wheel starts to go up. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father would take    me   to the top of the highest hill    and   we'd play this game, 'What Do    You   See' until we ran out of things    to   see. Do you ever play that? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to try? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. The Ferris wheel stops to let more people on.        Joha glitters beyond. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see a forest. It goes      on forever. There are giant      trees which keep getting bigger     and bigger over thousands of     years. Now you. The wheel begins to move a little higher and then stops. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see little trees growing on the forest floor, learning to grow with the little bit of light the big trees let in. Now you. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see the big trees getting bigger, their leaves and branches making one great green umbrella over all of Africa. The wheel stops again at its highest point. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see the sun growing weaker, giving off less light. I see the big trees dying because they cannot live without a lot of light. I see the little trees take over the forest because they learn to adapt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell a very good story. Her eyes sparkle, making her irresistible. PK leans forward. Maria turns her face towards him. Her lips part slightly. They kiss tenderly. The CAMERA RISES FROM them TO the star-littered sky twinkling above. The sky goes from black to grey as the CAMERA PANS DOWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sing-song)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't    hit you, can't hurt you. Can't    hit you, can't hurt you. Can't    hit you, can't hurt you. That's    it. Good. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geel Piet is punching at PK, slowly, with a large pair of gloves. The seven-year-old bobs and weaves quite expertly. Geel Piet stops, winded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wear out this old man. See? See how it can work? How little beat big?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.     But when do I get to punch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You not going to just punch, man. You going to combination. He demonstrates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-two. One-two. C'mon.       Now you. One-two. One-two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK does his best to mimic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh do we have     a boxer here. Yes sir. We build      you to eight-punch combination.      The Geel Piet eight. Then you catch     afire. One-two. One-two. Doc appears in the doorway. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is the next Joe Louis this morning? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try and hit me. Doc chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   C'mon. Doc takes a half-hearted swing.     PK bobs expertly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Try hard. Doc sets up and swings left, then right.     PK avoids both swings. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are amazing. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm going to learn the Geel Piet eight. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, yes. But right now you have to come learn the Beethoven Fifth for one hour so we can get to the cactus before it's too hot to plant. Did you bring her? PK points to a nearby bucket. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parchypodium Namquanium. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. Excellent. We make from you a champion and a brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furtive) Excuse me, big baas. But can I talk to the small baas? DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Geel Piet looks hesitantly from the man to the boy and then begins. GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every day I see you bring the bucket and in the bottom is some tobacco leaf. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It keeps the roots wet. GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens to the leaf after? DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little I use in some water to make a bug spray for the plants. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the rest we throw away. Geel Piet fidgets.   He drops his head, speaking low. GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you leave the pail when you go plant is a problem, small baas? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is like this. You see how hard the life is for the people here in prison. Only little pleasure they take from this hard life maybe sometimes when no one watching late at night -- a little smoke. Now with the big war in Europe tobacco is plenty hard to get outside. Inside it is gone. We are the forgotten in here. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have bunches of leaves at home. I'll bring a whole bucketful tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.   Mustn't do that, little baas. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Geel Piet means is it can be dangerous. Something the guards might not want the people to have. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with tobacco? Why wouldn't they want them to have it? DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong is people whose job it is to punish. After a little while it is all they know how to do. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do? DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for you to answer. The sound of a TRUNCHEON on METAL turns them to the door where SERGEANT BORMANN, a side of beef with a sadist's eyes, stands, truncheon in hand. He enters the room and circles the trio. BORMANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I smell something not right here, ay, kaffir? He pokes Geel Piet with his truncheon. GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (submissive) No, meneer sergeant. Everything okay here. Bormann swings his truncheon into the back of Geel Piet's knees, buckling the little man to the floor. BORMANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't fuckin' believe you. He glares at Doc and PK. BORMANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're up to something I'll find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bormann, still eying them suspiciously, exits.     Doc an PK help Geel Piet up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schweinhund.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  This old kaffir's okay. Sorry to make any trouble, little baas. We  just stick to the boxing now on.  Sorry, sorry. Geel Piet goes hobbling off, picking up towels.     Doc and PK go to exit. At the door PK turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geel Piet. Geel Piet turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I leave my bucket on the side by Doc's toilet when I practice piano. Geel Piet breaks out a smile he usually keeps to himself and exits. PK looks up at Doc who tossles his hair approvingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK, to me you are the champion of the world already. Come. Let us go box now with Mr. Beethoven. PK and Doc exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK in the ring is about to start sparring.    Solly gives him instruction as Morrie stands by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now at the end of the Geel Piet eight you do this... one-two... (he punches the air)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-two-three... the Solly Goldman thirteen. Okay? PK nods. Solly hits the BELL.   The sparring begins. works his way in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. That's it. Move him around. Jab jab. Slip slip. Now. PK pours it on, laying in the Geel Piet eight.   Solly is silently counting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... one-two... one-two-three. PK fires the last three punches like lightning and backs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. That's it. Now work around the defense. Jab jab. The opponent becomes aggressive.   PK starts dancing, slipping punches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you get away with this, Mr. G? Why don't they close you down? I mean, there are laws about blacks and white boxing each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a public match. Not in a gym. Not yet anyway. The Boer is a funny people. Outside the ring the black is not equal. Inside he is. But only in private, not in public. So I keep my mouth shut, the police go a little blind, and that's that. It's a crazy world, huh? A WHISTLE from across the gym draws Solly's attention. He and Morrie turn to his office where his assistant stands with the tall black man from the Schoolboy Championships. Solly's face takes on a serious ex- pression. He rings the bell. He turns to Morrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work him on the heavy bag. Solly heads for his office.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: turning away from his opponent. He and the tall black man trade a glance just before the man enters Solly's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: office and Solly closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK pounds the heavy bag as Morrie stands by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six, seven, eight, nine, ten. That's it. PK stops, relaxing. Morrie throws a towel over his shoulders. One of Solly's ASSISTANTS comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solly wants to see you two. PK and Morrie look at each other and head for Solly's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solly faces the door as it opens.    PK and Morrie enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to see us, Mr. G.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close the door. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone I got a lot of respect for asked me to make a request. He wants to put you in a match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young guy just turned pro. Gideon Mandoma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black fighter! They want him to fight a black fighter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a black township.   Sofiatown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the question. Not even up for discussion. C'mon, P.K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie goes to exit.   PK doesn't. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who asked you to ask? SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man who promotes all the fights in Sofiatown -- Elias Nguni. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you trust him? SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
