dialogues.text: In thirty years I know him, number one on the list. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're both out of your minds. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he tell you why he wants the match? SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you what he told me. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just talking boxing -- how do I match up with Mandoma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean besides    getting thrown out of school and    into jail, do you know what else    happens you do this? He's a     pro. The minute you fight him    you're a pro. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no purse being offered. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good career move. Risk everything to gain nothing. Very sound business sense. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Mr. Nguni I'll think about it. PK exits with Morrie steaming behind. They head for the locker room, PK clearly perturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.    What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well why don't you tell me what you do know. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an African myth about an outsider who comes one day and unites all the tribes into one against their oppressors. They call it the myth of Onoshobishobi Ingelosi -- the tadpole angel. That chanting at the school championships?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't heard it in years. PK begins to disrobe. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how did this honor fall on your broad back? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you about bringing tobacco to the prisoners at Barberton? Well after that was going for a while I learned that even though they could send and receive letters, they never did. They couldn't read or write. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you did it for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And after that? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clothing program for their families and a food program. One thing sort of led to another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see where 'angel' would be an appropriate title. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it was, uh, this Geel Piet who was really behind all of it, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was very good at pointing things out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man like that should be running a country, not rotting in prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not in prison anymore. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead. PK steps into the shower pulling the curtain closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK and Morrie exit the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS GYM TO MARIA
dialogues.text: talking to Solly.   She sees PK and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: PK and Morrie come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd surprise you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you succeeded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Goldman was explaining the theory behind the left hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats talking about the weather. You may have heard about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Morrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.   How d'you do. Solly's Assistant whistles for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, nice meeting you, Maria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you, Mr. Goldman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never had a girl come to the gym. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not such a bad thing, huh? Solly moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a pass to come out on a weeknight? Maria lifts her jumper a bit, displaying the results of treeclimbing on her knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your tree pass. PK moves Maria and Morrie off down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you box too, Morrie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look that daft?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie's the brains of the operation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He means the bank. Your boyfriend has a great head for literature but none for finance. They exit the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE WAY
dialogues.text: in the shadow of the alley stands, smoking a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Zulu)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you, Nguni.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you, P.K. They talk across the narrow street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have heard my request?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.    Why do you make it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman has thrown the sacred ox bones. She has made a fire and read the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That the Onoshobishobi Ingelosi who is a chief must fight the one who one day will be a chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's not true that I'm a chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows what is true and what is not. The legend of Onoshobishobi Ingelosi is very powerful among the people. They see you box the Boer and always you win. They have heard the stories from Barberton. The people live with little hope. They must see if the spirit of the boy still lives in the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And   if I lose? If the spirit of the   Onoshobishobi Ingelosi does not   exist in me anymore, then what will   they live with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less hope.   But still they must

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: see.   It is our way. At that moment a spotlight blinds them. A police car comes up the alley, stopping in front of them. The POLICE exit, threatening. POLICE #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this here? Maria is gripped by fear.     Morrie is cautious, unmovin PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old family servant, Officer. From home. We just ran into each other. POLICE #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papers, man.   Come on, be quick. Nguni reaches into his pocket. POLICE #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you coming from? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gym, sir.   I train there. POLICE #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you? MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm his manager. The Police look at each other and share a laugh. POLICE #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Maria) And you're the sparring partner, hey? The Police laugh. Police #2, satisfied Nguni's papers are in order, hands them back. POLICE #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have an hour to curfew and a long way to go, kaffir. Be off. NGUNI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subservient) Yes, baas. Going right now. Nguni moves off, no semblance of the proud man in his gait. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nguni. Nguni turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it. Nguni smiles and disappears into the night.    PK watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK and Maria stand by the tree set to climb over the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm scared for you, PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solly's a great teacher. He wouldn't put me in a fight I couldn't handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean about how involved you are with the black people. That scares me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you don't understand them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you did you wouldn't be so scared. You ever have a conversation with a black person?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides a servant. Maria's silence is her answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate it when you tease me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I am. He kisses her again. This time she responds, kissing him back. The kisses become more passionate, touching, feel- ing. The heat in both of them begins to rise when a car passes, its headlights arcing across the tree, startling them out of their passion. They cling to the shadows until the car turns the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better go. They kiss once, lightly. PK boosts her over the wall and waits until she is safely on the other side before run- ning off into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Oxford Board of EXAMINERS, eminent academics all, sit four across at a lecture table, looking absolutely musty with learning. Across from them PK sits, a folder in his lap. One man, PROFESSOR LEWIS, peruses the file in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to your submission you have ambitions to be a writer and the welterweight boxing champion of the world. Lewis reads the last sentence with a tinge of amusement in his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you   find seeking a career as a pugilist   and reading for a degree at   Oxford a bit, how shall we put it,   intellectually

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: incompatible. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Byron was a boxer, sir. And I've never heard anyone question his intellectual integrity. One of the other Examiners coughs theatrically to hide his smile. Lewis looks down the table at the man. LEWIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not recall Lord Byron actually engaging in matches for money. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, sir, there are several recorded instances of Lord Byron engaging in matches for quite large sums of money. EXAMINER #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite right. Yes. In   a letter to his wife Shelley makes mention of just such a thing. For  hundreds of pounds, actually. Lewis has heard enough. LEWIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's move along, shall we? As your presentational you've requested to read from a work of your own fiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. LEWIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, let us hope we'll be treated to the stirrings of another Byron. His sarcasm is not lost on PK.   PK ignores it, opens his folder, and begins to read. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Concerto for the Southland and the Death of Geel Piet. (pause) His name was Geel Piet -- yellow Peter. He was a mix of half the blood in Africa -- Dutch, Portuguese, Zulu, Sotha, and who knew what else. His father

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: deserted his mother before he was born. His stepfather threw him out to survive on the streets of Capetown when he was nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geel Piet is instructing a nine-year-old PK in the Geel Piet eight. Both boy and man are enjoying what they do -- and each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I met him he had spent forty of his fifty-five years in one South African prison or another. He was a thief, a con man, a black marketeer. As the narration continues, the SCENE FADES TO:

dialogues.speaker: TWELVE-YEAR-OLD PK
dialogues.text: with a much better grasp of the Geel Piet eight.      He Geel Piet seem closer than ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He may   even have killed a man or two in   his time. But despite all that he   was one of the kindest, wisest,   most self-effacing persons I ever   knew. He was my teacher; he was   my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK sits opposite a black prisoner who talks to him. PK, thirteen years old now, writes what the man says on a piece of paper. When he is finished, he folds it, puts it into an envelope, and hand it to the man. The man smiles, shakes PK's hand profusely, and exits. PK turns to Geel Piet who is on his hands and knees polishing the floor, seemingly part of the surroundings. Geel Piet and PK share a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geel Piet bore no  animosity, held no hate. Should   a guard beat him he regarded it as  self-inflicted,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the result of some carelessness on his part. To survive the system he lived in he became an expert in the art of camouflage, a master of the invisible. In this he strove to be perfect, and in the end it was his quest for perfection that provoked anger from above and killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite advanced after five years of planting. PK and Geel Piet are bent over a cactus, transplanting it. A group of prisoners on the way to a hard-labor work task march by. They chant a verse to Onoshobishobi Ingelosi. PK is a little embarrassed by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know every time they do that I want to jump up and say I'm just a twelve-year-old. I'm not anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To them you are. You are the one who brings the smoke, the one who writes the letters, the one who puts clothes on their children when they are cold. You are Onoshobishobi Ingelosi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know that's not true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is to say what is true and what is not true, kleine baas. Doc comes running up, excited, waving a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Allied armies have crossed the Rhine into Germany. It is almost over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great, isn't it? He turns to Geel Piet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subdued) Yes, kleine baas.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: You are a good    faker, Geel Piet. but you don't    think it's great at all. It means     you lose your star letter writer    and tobacco importer.

dialogues.speaker: GEEL PIET
dialogues.text: No matter that, Professor. We always manage here. What pains me most is I lose my boxer.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: I'll come back.

dialogues.speaker: GEEL PIET
dialogues.text: (adamant) No, kleine baas. You leave this damn place you don't come back never.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Geel Piet, when a painter finishes a work of art he doesn't lose it. He sends it out in the world so everyone can see the genius of his creation. This is what you are going to do. And to celebrate the launch of such a work of art as you have made our boxer here, I have composed an entire concerto -- 'The Concerto for the Southland' -- which it is my intention to play in concert for the prisoners before I leave.

dialogues.speaker: GEEL PIET
dialogues.text: Not possible. The kommandant never allow the people to have such a thing.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: He'll think it's a concert for him and the brass. But we'll know, ay? And the people will know.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: He'll never let black be with white here, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: If the black is part of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: orchestra, like the piano, he will. GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the people have no instruments in this place, big baas. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have their voices. Each tribe a different voice, a different language -- all singing together. It is brilliant, no? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except the tribes don't trust each other. They don't even talk to each other. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crestfallen) Oh. This is correct.    This stupid hatred. GEEL PIET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will do it for you, kleine baas. You are Onoshobishobi Ingelosi. You bring the tobacco. You write the letters. You put clothes on their children's bodies and food in their bellies. All you do is ask and they all sing for you. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right. Wunderbar.    You are the smartest of us all. Geel Piet smiles as he lifts the watering pot to exit. truncheon stops him. All turn to Sergeant Bormann. BORMANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kaffir smarter than all of us? You are a strange German, Professor. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That little maniac with the moustache in Berlin you admire. He is the strange German. And soon kaput, I hope. BORMANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's true you'll not be long for this place, eh, Professor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Sergeant.    God willing. BORMANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, too, little Rooinek.     But you, kaffir, Hitler comes or goes... He takes Geel Piet's hand. BORMANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are going to stay with me. He forces Geel Piet's hand closer and closer to a cactus with long thorns. BORMANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I will find out all your secrets once your friends are gone. One slip... He pushes Geel Piet's hands onto the cactus needle. Piet does not cry out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have you. He lets go of Geel Piet's hand.     Geel Piet removes it from the cactus, bloodied. BORMANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here. Geel Piet takes his watering can and goes. BORMANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Professor, they are not like us. A white man would scream bloody murder. Doc and PK glare at Bormann.    He smirks and walks away. PK (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the weeks went by and the date for the concert grew closer, my life was a whirlwind. PK and Geel Piet appear before various tribal leaders, talking, agreeing, shaking hands. PK (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having obtained the cooperation of all the tribal groups, we set about instructing them. Four men from each tribe were taught the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: intricacies of their group's parts. They were the choral leaders responsible for teaching the others. PK and Doc instruct. Doc plays the piano. PK leads the singers. Geel Piet turns the pages for Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At night the prison hummed with the men in their cells practicing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous guards patrol as the SOUNDS of the prisoners singing wafts through the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geel Piet instructs PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boxing instruction accelerated as well. It was as if Geel Piet was trying to give me every bit of boxing knowledge he had before we parted. And always from the corners and shadows Bormann watched and waited. Bormann watches PK and Geel Piet from the door of his room, his truncheon beating idly against his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photographer sets up a group picture of the boxing squad -- kids and guards. Geel Piet stands off to one side, OUT OF FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our boxing squad, the Barberton Blues, won the State Championship with a perfect record. I won at 100 lbs. It was my first championship. It made me want

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: more. The group disperses. PK beckons the photographer to wait. He grabs Geel Piet and forces him to stand, much to the little man's protestations, for a photo of the two of them. As the picture is taken Geel Piet has the widest smile imaginable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guards, all in crisp uniforms, patrol nervously, truncheons at the ready. The towers bristle with guns as hundreds of black prisoners file into the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally the night of the concert arrived. The prison atmosphere, normally tense, was keening. Each prisoner entering the yard is searched. It was prison policy to keep tribal rivalries boiling. Divide and conquer. The policy of control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was to be the first time in the history of the South African prison system that the tribes were allowed to mingle. And if trouble came, it would be the last. All the prisoners are seated on the ground behind Doc, who is raised with the piano on a small stage. Guards surround the prisoners -- a solid, edgy border encasing a black center. The front of the yard is filled with seats on which sit the Kommandant, his wife, assorted prison brass, politicians, and a smattering of the local Afrikaan Hierarchy. PK is overseeing the seating of the prisoners when Doc comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen my page turner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He asks a prisoner in Zulu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen Geel Piet? The man shakes his head.     PK looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reassuring) He will come. The Kommandant, all medals and polished leather, mounts the stage, signaling a beginning to the festivities. VON ZYL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Bormann? I need Bormann to translate to the prisoners. SMIT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Kommandant. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a problem here, Kommandant? VON ZYL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to address these filthy kaffirs but I don't have a translator. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll translate. VON ZYL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can speak Zulu, PK? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. VON ZYL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.   Listen up. He addresses the prisoners. VON ZYL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them this concert is the gift to them from the professor who, even though he is in prison, is not a dirty criminal like them but a man of culture and learning. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subtitled) The Kommandant welcomes you and looks forward to the great singing. VON ZYL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For such a man I am happy to do this. But one hair of trouble and it's finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subtitled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hopes each tribe will sing its best and bring honor to its people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One wrong move and you get marched back to your cells and don't come out for a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subtitled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says tonight let us be one people under the African sky. The prisoners break into spontaneous applause.   Von Zyl looks at PK, unsuspecting, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did a good job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor? He turns the stage over to the professor and takes his seat. The professor sits at his stool, poised. PK, in front of the singers, watches him for a cue. Doc drops his head. PK points to a group of singers. MUSIC and VOICE blend spontaneously. "The Concerto for the Great Southland" begins. Doc plays magnificently with great style. PK focuses on leading the singers. Each section, each tribe singing its own songs with its own distinct cultural imprints on rhythm, pace and tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: leading the singers in and out of the MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH TO TRUNCHEON
dialogues.text: being raised and lowered on a familiar back.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: PK is caught short by the flash.   He falters a bit, then regains his concentration.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH TO TRUNCHEON
dialogues.text: coming down on a familiar head -- Geel Peit's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instinctively the first four prisoners in each group, the leaders, stand and turn to face their people. They take up the lead. PK, distracted by his inner vision, runs off stage. Doc looks after him, worried, but keeps playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK runs through the empty cell blocks looking for some- one. PK runs through the corridors. He runs through the kitchens, the empty dining area, the SOUND of the concert chasing after him. He runs through the recreation area and past the boxing room when he hears a THUD, and another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bolts into the room and hits the light switch. The light over the ring comes on, illuminating Bormann, truncheon raised over the lifeless, broken body of Geel Piet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Startled, Bormann jumps out of the ring and runs off. PK scrambles into the ring and cradles the lifeless, blood- ied head in his lap, and begins to sob. PAN DOWN along Geel Piet's arm to his bloodied hand, holding the snapshot of him and PK. The Concerto grows LOUDER around PK until it enfolds him in its melodies. The voices of Africa, the music of Europe, reaching for a musical and spiritual crescendo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geel Piet died of massive internal hemorrhage, the result of Bormann's ramming a truncheon up into the little man's body until his entrails spilled out. When I reached him he was already dead. I sat there crying, stroking his head and crying with African

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: voices rising to heaven above, even as her blood soaked the ground below. The MUSIC SWELLS until the voices meld as one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four examiners all sit enthralled by the story. When PK looks up, a tear runs down his cheek. Lewis, who is visibly moved, clears his throat. Another man blows his nose with a handkerchief, covering his emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. You will be notified as to the University's decision by mail. PK rises and goes to exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Point of curiousity. PK turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your headmaster told me your work is somewhat autobiographical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Bormann, he was real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was justice ever served?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Sergeant Bormann died of cancer... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the rectum. PK turns and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solly Goldman sits behind the wheel of his old car. Two figures sneak out of the school and come running toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solly starts the engine as PK and Morrie hop in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to make a stop first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night won't last forever, boychick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll only take a minute. Solly puts the car in gear and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria is sleeping when a hand goes over her mouth.     Sh awakes, startled, to PK, finger to lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police car patrols the edge of the vast, dark, ram- shackle township, its cruiser light scanning the openings to the dark rutted alleys. It passes and disappears down the road. A moment later an African steps out of the shadows and whistles a signal.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE ROAD
dialogues.text: in the shadows, Nguni hears the whistle. He looks at his watch and up the road, tense, as another set of head- lights appears. Nguni steps back into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solly strains to see out his dirty windshield with the headlights as his car bumps along the unpaved road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night I escaped from the Tsar's Army it was just like this. Six of us -- four Jews, two Ukranians. Dark as anything. No streets. In the day we hid in bushes. At night we went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You deserted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whey they come take you   at thirteen years old and   tell you it's twenty-five years   in the Army, it's your duty to   desert. Nguni steps out right into the path of the headlights. Solly hits the brake hard, throwing everyone forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said the end of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes.    Sorry. I drive. He opens Solly's door with some urgency.       Nguni sees Maria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome, miss, welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Nguni turns into the township and is swallowed by the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car bounces along the rutted darkened streets of the township. The glow of smoldering cooking fires through open doorways offers minimal illumination to the squalid lives within. Maria peers out at a world she has never seen. As the car drives, women and children gather along the road peering in. Mothers point to PK, instructing their children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onoshobishobi Ingelosi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people have come from everywhere to see you. Maria takes PK's hand, a little nervous.      PK smiles a her confidently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are the men?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are to be witness. The muffled sounds of VOICES SINGING reaches them, grow- ing louder as they approach. Maria is tense. Nguni senses this. He turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No worry, miss. It is the sound of happiness. He stops the car at a door in a high wooden wall guarded by two big men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are here. Everyone gets out of the car and passes through the door which shuts behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nguni leads everyone down the hallway. PK is dressed to fight, hands taped, robe thrown over his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see why we have to weigh in. They're going to fight anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is very important the people see everything is correct. They come to    an arch which leads into a big empty room In the center    of the room stands a scale and a dozen Africans, all    dressed in worn but neatly pressed suits Mandoma, the    other man who attended PK's fight at scho clad only in    boxing gear, waits on PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Zulu)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you, Gideon Mandoma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you, PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want you to know you fight a man. Onoshobishobi Ingelosi is just a name I was given at Barberton Prison. It means nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not for you or me to say what it means. An old man, one of the dignitaries says something to Nguni.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. He motions for PK to step on the scale. PK does. The weight is duly noted. Mandoma then does the same. The twelve men are satisfied. They head for the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is time. He motions for the others to follow. PK goes to walk with Maria. Nguni pairs him with Mandoma. They exit the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party walks towards a big double door behind which a single VOICE PREACHING can be vaguely heard. Nguni knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors open to an entire soccer field jammed with humanity. A boxing ring is raised in the center. The only lights in the area directly over it. With the twelve witnesses in the lead, the party makes its way through a path in the crowd. An OLD WOMAN with a fly switch, not unlike Inkosikazi's, speaks from the ring. As PK passes the whispers start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onoshobishobi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Woman in the ring begins to chant.   The crowd picks it up. CROWD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onoshobishopi Ingelosi. Shobi shobi Ingelosi. PK looks back at Maria who is a bit unnerved, as are Morrie and Solly. He looks across at Mandoma whose face is a mask looking straight ahead, betraying nothing. The two men climb into the ring and stand in their corners. The Old Woman shuffles over and peers into PK's face. She mutters something inaudible, then turns to the crowd. OLD WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onoshobishobi Ingelosi. The crowd picks up the chant. She waves and the crowd goes silent. Somewhere in the darkness a single voice begins to sing "Nkosi Sikelel I Afrika" -- the African national anthem. The crowd picks it up. PK looks down to the front row where Nguni sits courteously attending to Maria in a seat of honor among the twelve men in suits. The African national anthem finishes. The BELL RINGS three times. The Old Woman is led from the ring. An Indian Referee in all white enters the ring and waves the two fighters forward. REFEREE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are listening to me please. When I am shouting break, you must break at once. When a knockdown is coming, it is for an eight count. No heads, no elbows. You fight clean or by golly I am giving you penalty points. Good luck, boys. PK and Mandoma touch gloves and go to their respective corners. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you see? Solly watches Mandoma dancing across the ring. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very tough fight. The BELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch the left hook. Mandoma comes charging across the ring and begins to fire everything in his arsenal at PK, overwhelming him. PK cannot get away from him and takes a series of devastat- ing combinations which end in a left hook to PK's jaw. PK drops like lead. The Referee starts counting. PK shakes his head clear and rises at eight. The Referee checks his gloves. There is a cut under his right eye. REFEREE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continue. Again, Mandoma comes charging hard. PK defends himself as best he can, trying to counter. But Mandoma's offense won't allow it. He beats on PK until the round ends. PK sits down in his corner. Morrie works on his eye. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, he hits like a truck. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going for the quick knockout. He can't keep it up. Soon the truck runs out of gas. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he catches me again like that I'll run out of gas -- permanently. The BELL SOUNDS. PK is hardly off his stool when Mandoma is on him, pummeling him. PK backpedals, bobs and weaves. Mandoma's punches come fast and furious, each one looking to end the fight. Mandoma gets PK against the ropes and bangs away. PK covers up. Mandoma punishes his arms and kidneys. PK swings back and es- capes. Mandoma pursues him. He catches PK with a body chop and then a chopping left. PK goes down again. The Referee starts to count. The crowd is completely silent. The BELL RINGS. PK returns to his corner, shaking his head, trying to clear it. He flops onto his stool. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's had it. He's got no strength in his punch. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could've fooled me. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- he's taking water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Mandoma, breathing heavily, sweating profusely, drinks deeply from his water flask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See. Where that water goes -- you go. Right to here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pokes PK's belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You put your punches there, you win. You don't, you lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BELL RINGS. Mandoma comes charging out. PK goes on defense. He hits Mandoma hard to the head. Mandoma whips around and hits him hard. PK spins and hits the canvas. His vision blurs, doubles. The SOUND of a WATERFALL fills his head.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: struggling to climb the rocks in the pool below the waterfall. He is halfway across this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three... four... five...

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: struggles to mount the fifth rock. He clings to it, wet, exhausted, as the water pummels him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... seven... eight... nine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK rises.    The crowd goes wild.      The Referee holds fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many fingers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a fight behind on points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandoma rushes in for the kill. PK feints and comes up under one of Mandoma's punches, burying a body shot into his gut. Mandoma grunts and backs up. PK pursues him. Mandoma tries to recover. He throws another big punch. PK ducks under it and puts two more hooks into Mandoma's stomach. Mandoma starts to back up for the first time in the fight. PK boxes, jabbing, feinting, pushing Man- doma around the ring, taking control. Mandoma, heading for exhaustion, throws another big punch in desperation. PK hits him with three punches in return. Mandoma swings again with a last desperate effort, and PK buries the Solly Goldman thirteen into every part of his body. PK steps back and with his last punch, puts Mandoma down. The crowd goes silent. The Referee counts Mandoma out. He raises PK's hand. Still, the crowd is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the shit now.      Nice knowing you, Solly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Solly look around at       the somber black faces ering in the shadows of the       ring light. PK looks  d Mandoma in silence. Mandoma        rises unsteadily. He in front of PK, staring into       his eyes, and then he PK's arm above his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onoshobishobi Ingelosi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd goes wild, chanting, singing over and over as PK and Mandoma stand in center ring, arms raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK stands with Maria by the tree they use to climb over the wall. In the b.g. Solly and Morrie wait in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Seniors Dance is two Saturdays from now. I would like it if you could escort me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria Marais with a rooinek at the Senior Dance? What will people think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll think what they think and I'll think what I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is that? Maria touches his face.   Her eyes soften.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I love you. PK swallows hard.   They kiss and embrace.     PK caresse her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would be honored to be your escort. Maria beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't doubt it for a minute. Solly HONKS the HORN. PK kisses Maria once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you a boost. PK stirrups his hands. Maria boosts up to the first branch of the tree. She crests the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for tonight.    You were great. She smiles and drops down behind the wall.     PK runs ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solly's car pulls up opposite the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie is sleeping in the back seat.         Solly and PK sitting in the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you and your manager first came to me with that meshuganah idea to be welterweight champion of the world you did not have a big believer here. But I gotta tell you. Now you do. In London lives Benny Rosen, the greatest trainer in the world today. When you go to your Oxford I give you a letter to Rosen. Whatever I can't do for you, he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mr. G. Solly pokes Morrie awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I give the address of a very good bookmaker. Teach you also a thing or two. Now, go on back to being fancy-schmancy English gentlemen. I'm proud of both of you. PK and Morrie exit the car and run back to the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As PK and Morrie jog toward their dorm a VOICE stops them from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. PK and Morrie stop cold.      They turn to St. John, up e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: for his daily constitutional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're up early, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best time for walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best time for running too, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have to put in the roadwork, sir. You know, keep those legs strong. St. John eyes the bruise on PK's cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Quite a fresh bruise there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tripped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should change your footwear. He looks down at their shoes. Both boys are wearing pro- per shoes; not at all what would be worn for roadwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To something a little more appropriate for... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: roadwork. Busted, the boys squirm uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. St. John fixes them with a look, and then walks off. boys bolt into the dorm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK and Morrie open the door and stop cold. Gideon Mandoma sits in a chair facing the door. He rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please excuse me for coming like a thief by the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You speak English? PK is surprised.   Mandoma nods. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a great fighter, Gideon. MANDOMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second greatest in this room. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you didn't come to talk about fighting. Mandoma shakes his head.   He waits for a moment, then begins. MANDOMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you say to me, Onoshobishobi Ingelosi means nothing, you are right. And you are wrong. The legend gives the people hope for a good tomorrow. But hope alone will not make a good tomorrow for the people. You cannot write our letters, get us clothes, food, work. These things we must do ourselves, so we can be part of this country's good tomorrow. If we are not, the hope will disappear. The people will grow tired. The tired will grow angry and there will be no good tomorrow for anybody -- black or white. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you asking from me? MANDOMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be part of something you must know what everyone else knows. We have our own knowledge. We need yours. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get our knowledge in schools, Gideon. We're not born with it. MANDOMA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it must be the same with us. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have schools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And teachers who cannot do more than their own ABC's. We have a system made not to teach us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am only seventeen years old, Gideon. I cannot teach five million people how to speak English and do sums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You taught the singing to thousands at Barberton Prison. You were only twelve. Mandoma rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a great fighter, PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second greatest in this room, Gideon. Mandoma exits through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK stands in front of a pondering St. John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are asking me for a lot, young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only asking you to put what you've taught us into practice, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are asking me to put the reputation of this school in jeopardy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reputation of this school, sir, is based on its integrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm aware of that. I'm also aware of what will happen if this ever gets out. We live in a country where the rules are being rewritten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'd better be careful to keep a firm hand on our pens... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... sir. St. John regards PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I will allow it on a trial basis. Here are my conditions: you tell no one; you operate at night on Saturdays when the student body is gone; you involve no one besides yourself and Mr. Levy. If you can comply, you can have your school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria and PK are about to race.    Maria is given a head start of ten yards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready.   Set.   Go! They both take off. Maria runs     as hard as she can. PK catches up to her. She strains     with the effort. PK crosses the finish line first.     Maria trips and falls, rolling in the sand. PK comes     back to her. He kneels down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're supposed to let me win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'd say I was being condescending.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were guilty of that when you gave me a head start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him and stands up.     They begin to walk alon the beach. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your formal yet? PK grows uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... no. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dance is only a week away. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria... (beat) I can't come to the dance. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) Why not? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an obligation. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you change it? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a permanent obligation. Every Saturday night... (beat) It starts tonight. Maria cannot believe what she is hearing. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're breaking up with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what could be so important that it takes all your Saturday nights? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really can't say. Maria starts to cry.   She throws her arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.K., I love you.     Please don't go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you are.   I can feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.   I'm just tutoring. Maria pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I started a school... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... for Gideon Mandoma and some others in the seniors library. Maria's sadness turns to anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm losing you to a bunch of kaffirs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not losing anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Are you escorting me to the dance? Are you going to see me on the only free night they give us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria, this is important to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my life's important to me. Damn you. She runs off in tears.   A pained PK doesn't attempt to go after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On an escarpment high above the dense green rainforest cover, PK and Doc move along the sheer cliff face with photographic equipment and rucksacks. PK notices Doc's labored breathing and slow movements. They reach some small cacti growing out of the side of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the cliff in full bloom. DOC (breathing hard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ach.   You see how beautiful? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever hear of glycerine, Doc? DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Going-To-Oxford-Smarty-Pants. Of course I know about glycerine. Triglycerine. Biglycerine. Monoglycerine. What do you want to know? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you don't use it. It's only a little pill under the tongue. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tongues were not made to put little pills under. When I have to start with that, I become something else. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, until you become something else, the little pills would make this easier on your heart. A CLAP of THUNDER cuts into their conversation.   Thick roiling rain clouds appear suddenly. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little pills or no little pills -- we don't find cover, we both turn into something else. Lightning splits the sky.   Rain begins to fall, pelting the escarpment. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look for a cave. Always in this kind of rock there is caves. Quick! Quick! PK starts to move horizontally across the cliff face like a spider on a wall. Doc follows. The rain becomes torrential. PK turns to look back at Doc. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at me.     Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK forges ahead.

dialogues.speaker: OPENING
dialogues.text: some 20 yards ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've found something. The rain is so heavy PK can barely make out Doc behind him. When he can, he sees the old man pause, breathing hard. PK makes his way back to Doc. Halfway there, Doc waves him forward and starts to move. PK reaches the small opening and slips in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK stoops in the small cave, dripping wet. A moment later Doc's foot appears at the entrance. PK helps him in. Doc slumps down, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay? Breathing too   hard to reply, Doc shakes his head in the affirmative.    PK looks out at the rain forming a sheer wall of water   outside. He turns to Doc, who is getting up, flashlight   in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exploring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just rest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty time for resting when I am something else. Look. He strikes a match.    A wind from inside the cave blows it side to side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When does a cave have wind?    This

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is more than some little cave, my friend. Doc crouches down and follows the beam of his flashlight to the rear of the cave where there is a small opening. He shines the light into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.   See?   There is a passage. Before PK can say anything else, Doc has wriggled through the small opening. PK, a bit peeved, takes his own flashlight and follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK crawls after Doc, making his way through the small tunnel on his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the pyramids are nothing more than man's attempt to recreate the first safe home our species had -- the cave. It is the ultimate safe resting place. The first place man could lay down and have a good night's sleep without worrying about waking up as something's supper. Doc stops crawling.   So does PK.   A DRIPPING can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear that? There is something waiting for us. Doc starts moving quicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hope it's not hungry. Doc squeezes out of the small space. PK joins him in a slightly larger tunnel, the same size as the first one -- stoop height.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better, ja?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that smell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of a sudden there is a RUSTLING noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? Doc recognizes the sound. He pounces on PK, knocking him to the floor and covering him with his body. Not a moment too soon. For a thousand bats fill the tunnel flying through.

dialogues.speaker: BATS
dialogues.text: flying wildly through the flashlight beams. In a blur, the bats are gone, disappeared into another tunnel entrance to the left.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Doc an PK rise slowly. The silence of the cave is punctuated by the DRIPPING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's stopped raining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who can think about rain when you are on the edge of the great unknown cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bats didn't come from a shoebox, Mr. Know-It-All. Doc heads off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think maybe sending you off to that fancy-shmancy school was not such a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was your idea. Your'e the one who pushed for me to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja. But who knew they do such a good job of boxing up part of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: your brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which part is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one where is all the questions. The curiosity center. Look. Ahead in the tunnel is a luminous glow, filling an entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I tell you? Doc and PK hurry on.

dialogues.speaker: TUNNEL OPENING
dialogues.text: As they come to a tunnel opening: a large cave, perhaps 200 feet wide by 100 feet high, filled with stalactites and stalagmites composed of pure, crystallized calcium carbonate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wunderbar. The whole chamber    glistens with an eerie phosphorescen Toward one end of    the crystallized room eight stalagmi grown up from the    floor cement to form a huge crystal slab some ten feet    off the floor. A buttress of stalg- mites drip off it    forming a natural, if uneven, stairw

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Doc and PK stare at the crystal cave in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many hundreds of thousands of years to make this masterpiece? Everything outside can change, P.K. This remains the same. We are in the heart of Africa, P.K. The heart of Africa. Doc, in his own world of wonderment, wanders down into the cave among the stalactites. PK follows, soon losing sight of Doc behind the large crystal columns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, if a person stayed here for 100,000 years what would be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: left? Crystal. Like a crystal mummy. Incredible, ja?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredible. Doc's preoccupation with death irks him.   He studies a piece of crystal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish we had brought the camera. Think there's enough light to shoot? Doc does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc? His concern rises. He moves through the maze of crystal, his pace quickening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc? Still no answer. His vision obscured, PK reaches the elevated slab. He clambers up the buttress for a better view. When he reaches the top he stops cold.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: lying on the crystal slab, eyes closed, hands folded on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not funny. Doc opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is incredible! The crystal. You can feel the life go right through you. Here. Doc rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (short)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   That's all right.   Can we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have only just gotten here. What's the matter, P.K.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All day long you've been talking about becoming something else, about dying. You never talked about dying before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm 87 next month.   It's natural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to a sixteen-year-old it's not. It's painful. Doc realizes what PK is saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are right. I am sorry. Sixteen-year-old ears should only hear life. Doc starts to whistle "The Marriage of    Figaro" by Moza The RESONANCE of the WHISTLING off the    crystal sounds beautiful, exotic. Doc beckons PK to     join in with him PK does so, hesitantly. Then pleased     with the sound a the feeling, more fully. Doc and PK exit through the stalactites, whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK and a very exhausted Doc enter. Doc sits down heavily on the bed while PK, shrugging off his rucksack, heads right for the small kitchen area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just set you up with some coffee here, so in the morning you won't have to bother making it. He begins to prepare the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to tell you what

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you can and can't talk about back in the cave today. I guess I just don't like to think of you being... (beat) PK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... becoming... (beat) ... something else. I know it's natural law and it's the way it is with everybody... (beat) I just wish it weren't with you. There is no reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc? PK turns to Doc, dead asleep, still sitting up. PK goes over and gently lays the old man down. He removes his boots and throws a blanket over him. PK blows out the kerosene lamp and goes to exit. He is about to hang their two rucksacks on two hooks by the door when Doc's voice turns him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here, Doc. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crystal cave will be our secret, ja? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise. DOC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja.  Good. I rest a little. (beat) The heart of Africa, P.K. Doc lays down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is asleep when his head hits the pillow. PK watches Doc's chest, washed in moonlight, rise and fall lightly. A sudden sadness falls over him. The corners of his mouth turn up in a bittersweet smile. He finishes hanging the rucksack and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK and Morrie stick close in the shadows. PK looks at his watch and then twenty feet away to the locked gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ! If someone would have told me this is where I'd be on a Saturday night, last term of my senior year, I'd call them batty. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you're going to owe me for the rest of your life on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That all? I figured you'd hold me to it longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get the insider friend's rate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, mate. A black groundskeeper comes walking along, seemingly on his duties. PK pokes Morrie.

dialogues.speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
dialogues.text: walks up to the gate. He looks left and right, then quickly unlocks it. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: PK and Morrie advance.    PK opens the gate.   As he does

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon Mandoma, followed by 15 men and 5 women, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you, P.K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you, Gideon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get inside before the whole bloody world sees us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie. He clasps Morrie's hand, first in a traditional hand- shake, then in an African handshake. Mandoma smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You some great friend. Morrie is taken by his sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.    Stay to the fence. The group moves out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Africans are seated around desks, waiting for Morrie and PK to tell them what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, class.     I know you don't understand a    word I'm saying, but part of    learning a language is hearing    it spoken. So -- I am P.K. He taps his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.K.  This... (taps Morrie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... is Morrie. Now you all have a chalkboard. He holds up the chalkboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chalk and an eraser.      I will say

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the letter. You will say the letter. I will write the letter. You will write the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie will check the letter. All right? Here we go. 'A'... (in Zulu)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... say it. 'A.'

dialogues.speaker: 'A.'
dialogues.text: The door to the library suddenly opens. Everyone freezes. Maria enters the room. PK is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. PK hurries over to Maria. Not a word needs to be spoken. Her presence says everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you might need some help. Or I can just sit and watch. PK hands her the chalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Class. This is Maria. She is now the teacher. (to Maria)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're doing alphabet, from the letter 'A.' PK takes up his position with Morrie, ready to check the chalkboards. Maria takes the front of the class.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK FACES
dialogues.text: before her, watching intensely.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: She battles the butterflies in her stomach as she writes an "A" on the blackboard. She clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: 'A.'
dialogues.text: No one says anything. Maria looks a little lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Zulu)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Repeat what she says. (to Maria)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it again.

dialogues.speaker: 'A.'
dialogues.text: She writes it on the blackboard again.   PK and Morrie trade a look and a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'A.'     Write 'A.' She mimes to the chalkboards. All the Africans obey. PK looks up from checking the students. Maria's eyes are twinkling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Africans are exiting. Maria, Morrie and PK stand, receiving their heartfelt thanks one by one. Mandoma is the last to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Maria)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are one brave Boer, Miss Maria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you are one lucky English. He kids PK.   PK blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Gideon. He playfully pushes Gideon out the gate and closes it. He turns to Maria and Morrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I   think I'll go... um... lay on   my back and count the cracks   in the ceiling. 'Night. Nice to   see you, Maria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Morrie. Morrie runs off. PK takes Maria around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am one lucky English. They embrace and kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.K.     Can I ask you a favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have to go in    or anything. You can hear the music    from outside. I'd love to     have one dance with you before    I graduate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel so good. Race you to the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a headstart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She takes off.     PK follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They disappear into the night.

dialogues.speaker: FIGURE
dialogues.text: in the shadows, watching them run off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK is working on a speed bag. Morrie comes running in with two open letters in hand. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made it!   We made it! He thrusts one of the letters at PK. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I couldn't bear the suspense after I read mine.   I had to open it. PK looks at his letter. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three months and we're out of here. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're out of here. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about? He snatches PK's letter. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) 'Dear sir. It is our pleasure to inform you that you have been accepted to matriculate at Trinity College, Oxford,' etc., etc., etc. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says nothing about the scholarship. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A technicality. Another BOY comes over. BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St. John wants to see you two in his study. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good news travels fast. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get showered and changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said to come as you are. Immediately. The Boy runs off, leaving PK and Morrie wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK and Morrie enter to a somber St. John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanted to see us, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Come in.     Close the door. As the door closes, BRIGADIER JOHANNES BRETYN, a quiet but formidable man, comes into their line of vision. Trouble is in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Brigadier Bretyn from the police department. Bretyn just nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has come to deliver, in person, an order to close the Saturday school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it is illegal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're only teaching them how to read and do sums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have certification to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince of Wales is a certified school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   But not certified for that

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sort of thing. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can he do this, sir? BRETYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I can do it. Would I be here if I couldn't? Come now meneer headmaster. Let's end this now. I have a full day ahead of me still. St. John meets Bretyn's steely eyes.   He cannot hold the man's gaze. ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resigned) The Saturday school is to be disbanded until further notice. BRETYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, meneer headmaster. Your cooperation in this matter is very appreciated. Good day. Bretyn goes to exit. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it can't go on like this forever. St. John tenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can't? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you're doing. BRETYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just doing my job. And if you'll take some advice, you should just do yours. Bretyn exits. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that really the end of it, sir? ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the moment I'm afraid it is. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we let them get away with it on our own grounds, it will never

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: change.   It'll just get worse. ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: History disputes you. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: History takes too long. ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it does. But it is never kind to those who try to hurry it. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel we should resist, sir. ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I, P.K. But this is not a subtle government. They mean to have their way and damn the consequences. And I cannot jeopardize this school, no matter how I personally feel. I'm sorry. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you were accepted at Oxford. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.   Received notification today. ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, congratulations. MORRIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. St. John looks at PK who remains silent. ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To both of you. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tight) Thank you, sir. An uncomfortable silence lingers. ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll talk before you go. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.   Will that be all? ST. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK turns immediately and exits.     Morrie and St. John trade an uncomfortable look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK walks down the hall, anger building in his face. exits the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK comes up to the main gate.     A GUARD stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to see Maria Marais please. The Guard checks his list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. She's not allowed visitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if I could just talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. PK backs away and moves off down the street.     He turns the corner.

dialogues.speaker: TREE
dialogues.text: he uses to scale the wall is in the process of being cut down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie is asleep.   PK wakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie.   Morrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it? He looks at his watch and turns over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see it later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Come on. He pulls Morrie out of bed.     Morrie groggily starts pulling his clothes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, when we get to Oxford -- separate rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there some girl out there waiting for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Stunning. Breasts like casabas. Just waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. PK throws a jersey into his chest and pulls him out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The campus is swaddled in early morning fog. PK and Morrie stand on the side of the school chapel while a black groundsman opens the door to the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're fooling yourself into thinking the bastards won't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: come after us in here. The groundskeeper opens the door to the basement.       T boys enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK switches on a light switch to a cavernous space cluttered with old desks, blackboards and church pews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a church. Didn't you ever hear of the Christian concept of sanctuary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But I'm not the one who has to respect it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even the Boer has limits, Morrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he does, but I'd still like to see a big bolt on the inside door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Levy? The Caretaker pulls a large deadbolt out of his pocket, with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandoma and PK, both with protective equipment on, square off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now move it nice and easy, the both of you. Time. PK and Mandoma circle.   Mandoma throws a jab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want us to close the school. PK counters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandoma lays in a combination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are still game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK throws a combination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are we.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you two find some other time to chat. This is a boxing ring, not a social club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandoma and PK start boxing in earnest, both smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A watchman makes his rounds. He passes by     Maria's window. When he is gone, PK appears from     behind a tre He taps on the window. Maria comes to the     window and sees him. Her face lights up. She opens      the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cool) I was in the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria puts her finger to her lips and waves him in. climbs through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria points to the door. She puts a record on her phonograph. She turns to PK and embraces him fiercely, holding on tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) They're sending me away to school in Pretoria. I told my father I wouldn't go. He said if I didn't he'd see they arrest you and ruin your chances. I couldn't let him do that.

dialogues.speaker: PK'S PAINED FACE
dialogues.text: as he holds Maria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next week. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to make love to you, P.K. PK's eyes fill with her words.     She releases him.    T look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. PK leans forward and kisses her, awkward, as if for the first time. As their lips part, their breath shortens. Maria moves forward slowly, lifting PK's hand to her breast. He touches it. The heat builds. Passion overwhelms them. They begin to make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria sleeps peacefully in PK's arms on her small bed. PK lies awake, staring at the ceiling. He rises quietly so as not to wake her. He pulls on his clothes, gently brushes a wisp of hair away from her eyes, kisses her forehead, and exits through the window into the breaking dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK and Morrie    stand by a side gate near the athletic field looking    alertly about. The gate  opens. The Africans led    by Mandoma come through.  PK and Morrie greet them.     When they are all through Morrie closes the gate and    runs after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man with a walkie-talkie sits in the shadows, watching 25 people run across the athletic field. He talks into his walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light switch is  on. The four lights above the center of the room  illuminate a classroom area -- desks set up in neat rows  with stools, a blackboard. The other furniture has  been piled high against the walls on either side of the  room where the light does not reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll all be seated we can begin. The Africans head toward their desks.    PK turns to Morrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far so good. Morrie's response is to throw the new deadbolt into its slot with a skeptical eye. PK takes his place at the head of the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
