dialogues.text: I want to thank you all for having the courage to come tonight. (in Zulu)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Zulu)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be teaching the first part of class tonight and Mr. Levy will teach the second. A woman whispers something to Mandoma.     Mandoma raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Marais.   Will she not be coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This causes a flurry among the women. PK writes on the blackboard the word "see."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See. He says the word in Zulu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.    You see.     We see. He moves his hands, eliciting response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.    You see. We see. PK holds up a book with a picture of a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see the boy. PK holds up another picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girl.    I see the girl. ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see the girl. There is a KNOCK on the door.       Everyone freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.K., it's me. Morrie pulls the bolt, opening and shutting the door quickly. PK and Maria look at each other. MARIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to say goodbye to my students... (beat) ... and to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four women in the class speak in unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the girl. Maria smiles, surprised. The moment is shortlived as a SOUND from behind the pews in the rear of the room turns everyone. In the shadows, risen from behind the piles of furniture against the two opposite walls, stand 20 policemen with long menacing riot sticks. Bretyn steps into the light. Mandoma gives a command and the Africans form a phalanx around the women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once warned.     Twice punished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're violating the sanctity of the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You are with your damned race mixing ideas, rooinek.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIE
dialogues.text: by the door, slowly slipping the bolt lock, trying to remain innocuous while doing so. PK sees him and trades a look with Mandoma, who also sees what Morrie is doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least let the women go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want everything to be equal, little Boetie. Why not men and women too? Just then Morrie throws the bolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now! He goes to charge out the door, but to his chagrin the door does not open, locked from the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bretyn smiles cruelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locks keep people out but they also keep them in. He has walked right up to Morrie, not taking his eyes off Morrie's for a moment. Morrie meets his gaze evenly. The moment is broken as Bretyn's baton slams into Morrie' stomach, dropping him to this knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up, you bloody commie Jew! He bangs Morrie hard in the jaw, knocking him out cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain. The two police lines start to move towards each other, sandwiching the Africans, PK and Maria. Mandoma gives an order. The blacks pick up anything they can to face the inevitable--stools, chairs, a flagpole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    Wait.   We'll leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late. You never should have come. At the ready. The two police lines tense to charge forward. The blacks brace to defend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!    Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. The police charge from both ends of the room, yelling, clubs held high. The Africans respond with their own war cry and engage the club-swinging police. A policeman swings at PK who ducks and buries a hook into the man's ribs followed by another to his jaw. The man goes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie has risen to take a policeman out with a stool over his head. Two other police beat Morrie from behind.   He goes down once again under their brutal clubs.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: PK turns just as another club comes for his head. He slips past the blow and punches out his assailant with a lightning combination. As the man falls another cop charges from behind.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: PK turns off-balance. Maria leaps. The club cuts through the air. Maria is caught flush on the forehead as she comes between PK and the club. She falls to the floor dead. PK swings a stool with all his might, breaking the cop's face open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria! PK drops to the fallen girl's side. He is frantic at the sight of her gaping bloody wound and the sight of her open blank eyes. The battle raging around him recedes before his pain and rising rage. All at once he explodes, screaming like a madman. He leaps at Bretyn and bangs one punch after another into the startled man. Bretyn's face is broken over and over against PK's fists. Still PK keeps pounding blow after blow into the fallen man. Three cops descend on PK and beat him mercilessly until he drops to the floor, unconscious. Mandoma is hit hard and goes down. The few Africans left fighting go down before the withering assault of clubs, fists, and boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria's funeral. Hundreds of Afrikaaners are gathered. Daniel Marais and his wife stand by the open grave, grieving, as the minister reads the final prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffin is lowered. Daniel Marais steps forward and shovels the first dirt down after it. As Marais looks up he sees PK standing behind the mourners, 20 yards off. His anger replaces grief. Marais advances towards PK, clutching the shovel as a weapon. Several MEN restrain him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel.    No. Marais glares at PK. All of a sudden a thousand African voices cut through the air, SINGING songs of mourning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thousands of Africans and a smattering of whites have gathered outside the cemetery. The singing rises from them. Gideon, Morrie, St. John and Solly stand in front of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marais glares at PK, tears of rage in his eyes. PK stands his ground. Marais turns away, back to his daughter's grave. PK stands, tears streaming down his cheeks, as the SINGING ENGULFS the SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK sits at his desk filling out application forms. Morrie enters.   He picks one up off the desk and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're applying to South African universities?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case the scholarship doesn't come through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you so bloody stubborn? You don't belong in a South African university any more than I belong in the priesthood. Will you take my father's loan? PK takes the applications back just as a TELEGRAPH DELIVERY BOY comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There a Mr. P.K. here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your scholarship. Morrie grabs the telegram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign here.   Odd name -- P.K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waldo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not one to talk about names. Morrie scribbles his signature and proceeds to open the telegram. PK snatches it away from him. He pulls the telegram out. His face falls to worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc's missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK walks through the small house followed by Commandant Von Zyl. Nothing is out of place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since his pneumonia last year I've had one of the men drop by once a week to see if he needed anything. Of course you know the professor. He never did. PK looks out at the cactus garden, watered now by drip irrigation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the beginning of the week he wasn't home so I decided to drop by myself. Waited a whole day here. When he didn't come back I sent search parties. After three days I sent the telegram. Seven days is a long time for him to be gone. Do you have any ideas where he went? PK looks at the pegs where the rucksacks hang.    There is only one hanging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK hikes along, watching the trail. His eyes spot something. He kneels over the remains of a small campsite. PK touches the ashes. His eyes rise to the escarpment soaring above the jungle floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK climbs along the cliff face.   He drops down into the entrance to the crystal cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK stands at the bottom of the crystal slab almost dreading what he will find. He resolutely climbs the stalagmites to reach the top. PK's eye level shifts from below the slab to even with it, then to above it. As his sight rises Doc's corpse comes INTO VIEW --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: laid out, serene hands clasped on his chest. From above the stalactites drip onto his body ever so slowly, turning him, molecule by molecule, into crystal. PK stands off to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a small metal box by Doc's feet.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: PK picks it up and opens it. Inside is a letter.    PK unfolds it, and with trembling hands reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Mr. Schmartypants. It did not take you so long to figure out what happened. I hope you forgive me for not saying goodbye, but I did not think it would be necessary between us. What could I say you don't already know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I love you with all my heart? That you have given me more in our ten years of friendship than three lifetimes could fill? That the last thoughts I have before becoming something else will be of music, cactus, and you? You know all this. PK turns the sheet to page two which is a whole side of music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night this music came into my head. It is my music for Africa. My music for you. So go. Be welterweight champion of the world. Be a writer. A great writer. Remember -- the only thing between a dream and a reality is you. Until we meet again, your friend, Doc. PK looks down at Doc as a PIANO CONCERTO, beautiful, haunting, BEGINS TO PLAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK plays the music Doc wrote with only the moonlight illuminating the page. The music is soul-stirring, rich, evocative. Tears run down PK's cheeks. PAN FROM PK THROUGH the CACTUS GARDEN to the FULL MOON illuminating the African veldt as the MUSIC dominates and then FADES into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The overnight train pulls in.         PK disembarks.

dialogues.speaker: STATION CLOCK
dialogues.text: reads 6:30. PK exits the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK comes down the street. A police car sits in front of the gym. The two cops inside eye PK. He eyes them back and enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gym is empty. PK enters and is stopped by the uncustomary silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?     Mr. G?     Anyone here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In here. PK heads for the office. He finds Solly packing up his mementos from the cluttered office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Goldman, why isn't anybody

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: training?    What's going on? SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A repeat performance of history, my boy. Solly Goldman's being deported. Of course last time I didn't have the luxury of being able to pack. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what reason? SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their reason is that I'm here illegal. I didn't enter the country with a passport. Like the Czar was issuing passports to Russian Jews in 1910. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is because of me, isn't it? SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, boychick. This is because of them. They are the problem, not you. Don't ever think different. You look tired. Want a glass tea? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.   I have to get back to school. Solly opens his arms.   PK hugs him. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got your head screwed on right. Don't let these meshuganahs screw it on wrong. Now go on. You want to find me, look at Benny Rosen's gym in East End, London. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for everything. SOLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not finished yet. PK smiles and exits. Solly waits for a moment, then goes back to packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK comes up to the school gates. He notices two plain- clothes police cars just across the road. PK enters with a growing sense of uneasiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK hurries down the hall to his room. He opens the door to Daniel Marais, sitting at his desk, reading from his fiction-filled notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a very good writer. The subject matter is a little inflammatory but the style is interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to inform you that you will not be receiving aid from the National Scholarship Fund. Neither will you be admitted to any of the South African universities. Here are your applications back. He hands PK the applications as he rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you when you came to my house. I am first a member of my tribe and I will defend it any way I know how. He and PK glare at each other, implacable enemies. Marais exits. PK looks out his window, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MARAIS
dialogues.text: walking off across the campus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't want you here any more than they want me.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: PK turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the hint. Screw the scholarship. Come on. Let's leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I leave or if I stay in South Africa it's because I choose to, not because they choose for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a small handbag, throws a few books into it and Doc's picture. He picks up his notebook and packs that too. He goes to exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save my place at Oxford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK exits the room. Morrie chases after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.K., goddammit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs PK, stopping him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save my place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrie's grip releases. PK walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds upon hundreds of black laborers and white mine workers descend into the mines. A milling mass of disenfranchised humanity come to work the underground hell of the copper mines. PK exits the management shack and walks through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Morrie.     Here is how it works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The copper of the mines in Northern Rhodesia is mined below ground. All day a behemoth of a man, a diamond driller, works a stope which is like the top of a funnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge diamond driller at work drilling and blasting in the stope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Setting charges and drilling the rock. The only way for the raw ore he takes from the sides of the stope to get to the haulage below is to pass through the spout of a funnel and out the steel doors at the bottom -- sixty feet down.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPED DOORS AT BOTTOM OF FUNNEL
dialogues.text: opening, as the haulage cart fills with ore and moves away on the track in the tunnel below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halfway down the spout area is a set of six tungsten steel bars called a grizzly which catch all the rocks too large to make it through the funnel mouth to safe haulage.

dialogues.speaker: GRIZZLY
dialogues.text: six bars with men working them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are taken care of by a grizzly, an explosives expert whose job it is to keep the ore flowing, and since when the ore doesn't flow, neither does the money, working the grizzly is a very crucial and therefore very well-paid position. Three months'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: work earns a year's    stay at Oxford. Yesterday,     on receiving my blasting license    from the School of Mines, I    signed on to work the bars for a    year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crude place where the bar runs the back length of the room and the bare concrete surroundings offer nothing in the way of diversion from the main purpose of being there -- to drink hard and long. THOMAS, a harsh, ruddy-faced Welshman, the School of Mines instructor, downs a drink, pours another and looks up at PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?     To sign on for a year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said I was the best you ever taught, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you are, boyo. The absolute best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But even the best doesn't survive a year on the bars. Down in that damn tube the luck runs out sooner than later. You may be a genius at reading the rock but you ain't no fuckin' fortune teller. Thomas throws back another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You worked grizzly a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And let me show you what I have to show for it to this day. He holds up his hand.   It shakes noticeably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's thirteen years after the fact, boyo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NOISE from the doorway turns Thomas's attention. He looks over as four huge men enter, drillers, men whose faces and bodies are as hard and massive as the rock they work. One of the men pauses at the door and grabs his head as an enormous jolt of pain runs through it. He shakes it off and follows his friends to a table. Thomas looks concerned. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong? THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unconvincing) Nothing. The BARTENDER comes over and puts another shot in front of Thomas. BARTENDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One double brandy. One... (derisive) lemon soda. He puts the lemon soda in front of PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, then. Thomas lifts his glass. THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On being the best damned blaster ever taught by Ian Thomas. Cheers. Thomas and PK clink glasses.     Thomas knocks his shot b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another. The bartender pours another. THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you don't want one? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like the taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taste?     You don't drink for the taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hand. It is steady now. He fixes PK with a portentous stare. Thomas looks over at the table of drillers. The man with the headache is downing one shot after another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell's comin'. He draws PK's attention to the drillers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drillers. He's got a powder pain from breathin' too much of that damn gelignite. The pain's bad enough. Mixed with a little alcohol it's fuckin' lethal. He watches the driller down two more shots of liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.   We ain't got much time. Thomas directs PK towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two most dangerous things you'll ever see in your life, boyo: a hangup of rock that won't blast free on first shot and a driller with a powder headache drinkin'. As they reach the door the behemoth explodes with a roar. He grabs his head and staggers backwards; a mad look comes into his eyes. His three huge frineds rush to grab him.   He throws them off as if they were ants. He rips a table out of its bolting to the concrete floor and flings it across the room. The men drinking in the bar, all tough cases, begin to flee. Thomas grabs PK whose eyes stare in amazement as the behemoth struggles against his three massive friends and pulls him out of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pk is watching a rugby match being played at twilight. The players are a rough, brutal bunch and play their

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: game accordingly.   Fights continually break out. Off a play a fight breaks out. One of the men is kicked unconscious. Two of his teammates carry him off the field, dumping his body unceremoniously like a sack of potatoes on the sidelines. They run back as play resumes. PK turns and walks back through the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A company-built miner's camp. Cement huts with steel doors and corrugated roofs. No shrubbery, only dust, cement, and the roughest-looking bunch of men assembled on earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Morrie. To answer your question: yes--sports are played here, but only in the loosest sense of the words "sport" and "play". The rules are different for everything, in games as well as in the rest of our lives. The managers, the foremen, the company people. They live apart from the miners. They have families. Proper gardens. Sunday dinners. The miners--the crud, as we are called -- don't. This is a society of men, many of whom have pasts better left behind. Future does not apply. It is a society only in the loosest sense of the word. The laws of survival are simple-- you either do or you don't. PK comes down a side street. A half a dozen men at cards, hard-faced desperadoes, see him pass, eyeing him closely. PK averts his eyes. From behind his back comes the sound of LIPS PUCKERING loudly, indecently. PK swallows hard. The sound of a CHARGE turns him to the six men bolting from their card game after him, whooping with lascivious intent. PK takes off. The chase takes PK and his pursuers flying through the streets of the camp, past one identical cement hut after another.  People watch, disinterested. No one raises a hand to help. PK comes racing around the corner to three of the men

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: blocking the street in front of him. He whirls. The others catch up behind, yelling and hooting. The two lines advance. PK gets ready. When the first man is close enough he hits him hard, breaking his jaw. He swings at another, catching him flush in the face. But then the rest are upon him. Even though PK fights like hell, he is overwhelmed. The blows come from everywhere, beating him to the ground. His arms and legs are firmly grabbed by four men. He is banged hard face down onto a concrete table. The fifth man pulls down his pants and the sixth begins to undo his own fly. All the men scream obsceni- ties, anticipating the rape. PK struggles like hell to no avail. As he is about to be violated, a roaring giant of a man tears into the pack like a bear shredding dogs. He scatters the men, knocking some unconscious, sending the rest to flight. He stands over PK, a looming block of granite with a wild black beard and coal-black eyes. His intent only becomes clear as to whether he is claiming a prize or helping a friend when he offers PK his hand, lifting PK effortlessly. He examines PK's bruised face with some concern and then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Rasputin, I had them right where I wanted them. Another minute they were done for. Rasputin claps PK on the back and addresses him in Russian, to which PK responds with a smile. The two men walk off together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TCHAIKOVSKY SYMPHONY plays on a rickety   OLD RECORD PLAYER. PK works out on a speed bag and    a heavy bag he has hung in the room while Rasputin, the   giant Russian, sits next to the record player, finishes   drinking a bottle of brandy, tears running down his   face as he fol lows the symphony. When he finishes the    bottle he take another one out of a case sitting by his   side and begin to drink anew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friendships are rare--arising out of mutual need rather than

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: any shared interests. But they do exist and even flourish. Except between the drillers and their grizzlies. No one wants to get too close to the man who might be buried at night by what you drilled loose in the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK inspects his nightly quota of gelignite charges and fuses. Five Africans, all serious faces, keep their eyes firmly on PK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Africans who come here looking for work are driven by a different desperation--drought, famine, locusts. Satisfied with the equipment, PK nods for the box to be closed. ELIJAH, his head man, closes the boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come and risk their    lives to send money back home to    the families sitting on the    barren farms, starving, waiting    for death or rain. When the boxes are closed the other five men in the crew lift them and follow PK out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator descends into the mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superstition runs deep in them, so a good grizzly man attracts a good crew. On the bars, the longer you live the luckier you are. And by association -- they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK and his crew make their way through a narrow tunnel and come to the grizzly. It is dark. The only light comes from the lamps attached to their helmets. Boulders litter the bars. PK and Elijah are onto the bars first.   Their light beams move along across the boulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baas.   Baas. PK turns to Elijah. His lamp catches Elijah's face which is looking upward. PK looks up. His POV in the narrow bands of light: a bunch of rocks big and small, packed into the funnel. His face grows dim.

dialogues.speaker: HANGUP OF ROCKS
dialogues.text: Five feet across a rock wall with stones of all sizes blocking up the funnel's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hangups are the worst of it. When the top of the funnel gets blocked up and the ore won't flow. PK scales the sheer rock wall of the funnel, his shirt packed with explosives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only way to unblock it is to set a charge to blow inward. And the only way to do that is to set the charge in mud, which means climbing up to the mouth of the stope and coming face-to-face with the devil. PK reaches the hangup. He works at taking a prepared parcel of gelignite sticks and jamming them carefully into a crevice. As he does the hangup creaks deeply, shifting, ominous. A few rocks fall. PK freezes, holding his breath.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICANS
dialogues.text: peeking out of the safety shaft below, terrified. Elijah remains on the grizzly bars, his light shining on PK.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: holding very still, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes the rock doesn't need the provocation of explosives. Sometimes the earth shifts... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a pebble moves... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you talk too loud... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and in the moment before you are turned into something else by fifty tons of rock you understand why it is called grizzly. PK finishes setting the charge. He scales down the wall. A large rock is expelled from the hangup and comes bouncing down the sides to the funnel, just missing PK, crashing through the bars below. PK freezes. Elijah holds his breath.   The crew in the safty tunnel quakes. Nothing happens. PK comes down the rest of the way. He takes the cordtex rope dangling from the bomb and inserts a fuse. He nods to Elijah. Elijah lights a cheesa stick. He hands the glowing stick to PK. PK waves towards the tunnel. One of the Africans sounds the WARNING WHISTLE. Two blasts followed by two blasts. PK nods for Elijah to be off. Elijah stands his ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wait for you, baas. PK lights the fuse. Elijah takes off like a scared rabbit for the safety of the shaft. PK is right on his tail. The fuse travels quickly toward the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah trips. PK, coming behind him, grabs him by the collar and flings him into the safety tunnel, diving after him a second later, just as the BOMB EXPLODES. A few rocks come down, but nothing else. The Africans look at each other with real apprehension. PK rises from Elijah and peeks out.

dialogues.speaker: HANGUP
dialogues.text: is still in place. PK studies the hangup, stepping out onto the grizzly, listening, looking. The hangup groans. The Africans are petrified at the mouth of the tunnel. PK stops midway on the bars. He studies the hangup intently, then picks up a rock. Choosing a target he heaves the rock with all his might toward the hangup and runs like hell. The rock hits the hangup. PK springs off the grizzly, right into the Africans as the hangup thunders down. Dust and small rocks fill the safety tunnel. When the avalanche has stopped PK raises himself off the Africans. They are all covered in dust but smiling and babbling, happy to be alive. PK peeks out and up. He signals to Elijah who hits the LL-CLEAR WHISTLE. Three blasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's clean her off and call it a night, hey? Happy, the Africans lift shovels and crowbars to clear the bars. As they pass PK they touch him reverentially as one would an icon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Africans think the longer you survive the luckier you are. And the luckier you are the longer you survive. I know there's something inherently wrong with their logic. Still, I'm beginning to see their point. Especially with less than six months to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK and Rasputin play a game of chess as TCHAIKOVSKY plays in the background. There is a KNOCK on the DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. JOCKO, the bookmaker, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, man. If you'd let him win once in a while we could take a little book on it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't care if he wins.     He just likes to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which    is why I'm about visiting you.     You've come on the board, man.     There are odds on your making    it or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in your favor, my boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you telling me this, Jocko?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you come up on the boards, boyo, it's time to bow out. It's an omen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bow out you can't make book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK, it's not a bet I want to collect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Jocko, how high will the odds go on something like this? JOCKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shorter your time, the higher they go. With you probably ten, twelve, thirteen to one when you're short a month. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the odds hit the top put me in against all bets for two hundred quid. JOCKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not come here to solicit your bet. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. I appreciate it. But if you don't take it, someone else will. JOCKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All  right. You're a bleery fool. And  I'll be prayin' every night it's  the only bet I ever have to pay  off on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so will I. Jocko rises to exit. JOCKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should let him win once in a while. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he wins it won't be because I let him. Rasputin says something in Russian as he moves a piece, excited to have taken one of PK's pieces. PK turns and checkmates him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checkmate. Rasputin laughs, speaks in Russian, and starts to set the board up again. Jocko exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator descends into the shaft. PK and his crew exit. There is a low sound of a blast, muffled, that stops them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear a blast whistle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, baas. Then after a moment the vague sound of a drill leaps through the rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard a drill at night. The Africans get nervous.   They chatter to one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a ghost. It's just some driller trying to squeeze extra pay. Come on. PK moves forward. The Africans follow him out of the elevator with reluctance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK steps out onto the bars with Elijah and examines the debris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baas. There is a tremor of fear in his voice.   PK follows Elijah's face upwards to a hangup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the first bloody thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad sign, baas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad drilling's more like it. Come on. Let's get it going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah goes back to fix the charge while PK studies the hangup. He hears the Africans talking in the dark. When his light points on them they stop, turning their heads away. Elijah comes back with the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say juju. Bad magic is in the mine tonight. PK heeds the warning, somberly. He takes the bomb from Elijah and starts to climb the wall. TRACK with PK as he makes it up to the hangup. He quickly seals the bomb and drops the cordtex.

dialogues.speaker: ELIJAH
dialogues.text: on the bars, catching the rope. He is growing more nervous by the moment as he fastens the fuse.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: making it down the side of the tunnel. The hangup shifts.   PK freezes.

dialogues.speaker: THE AFRICANS
dialogues.text: peeking out of the safety tunnel, scared.

dialogues.speaker: ELIJAH
dialogues.text: scared, but standing his ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: making it back onto the bars. He carefully makes his way to Elijah as the hangup sends some pebbles down. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's playing with us tonight. Fuse set? Elijah nods. PK holds his hand out for the cheesa stick. Elijah lights the flare. He goes to hand it to PK. PK notices Elijah's hands shaking. He sees the fear in Elijah's eyes. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. ELIJAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stay with you, baas. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an order. Elijah, released from his responsibility, retreats quickly. PK stands holding the flare, a little distracted by Elijah's fear, wondering. Elijah sounds the BLAST WHISTLE. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One... two... three. A MUFFLED BLAST comes from the other side of the hangup deep in the stope. PK freezes, confused, and then a SECOND BLAST goes off. The hangups starts to give. And ANOTHER BLAST. PK lights his own fuse and runs like hell over the bars toward the tunnel. The hangup, loosened by the explosions inside, gives before PK's bomb ignites. The rock is crashing down. PK races the rock. The tunnel is within sight. The men yell for him to jump. PK is about to leap when a rock hits the bar, bounces up, and catches him in the stomach. He  loses his balance and goes over the side as the hangup comes crashing down. PK hits the wall of the lower funnel -- once, twice -- and then lands in the soft stuff -- the shale flake, cushioning the steel doors below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: against the wall of rock. A rock ledge carelessly left when the funnel was originally built. PK rolls under it. A moment later fifty tons of ore in large chunks and small chunks and dust comes crashing down, burying PK. He lays there, semiconscious, buried but alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The falling rock has stopped. The   funnel is full. The bars as well. Elijah and the crew   look out of the safety tunnel tremulously. Elijah   looks up the stope. His light catches a man at the very  top of the stope climbing out. Elijah pulls the WARNING WHISTLE.   Five blasts over and over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men hear the WHISTLE and stop work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men shovelling ore stop shovelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rasputin is timbering with his crew, fitting huge timbers into place, making new haulage, when he hears the whistles.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: He yells at his crew to grab the tools and he runs off down the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deep hole has been dug through    the rock piled in the lower funnel. Rock comes up in     a bucket and is carted off. Timber is passed down. A      crowd of miners, black and white, watch and help where    they can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead.   No doubt about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give me a fair odds on ten quid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it a sixer and you got me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone else?   Six to one he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rasputin works like a man possessed, piling rocks in the bucket to be passed up, shoring timbers as they are passed down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah is pointing up the stope to two Mine Managers as dozens more mill around, hauling the rock out, trying to help. TWO MINERS observe Elijah and the managers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says someone was up there. Blasted it out on PK from the other side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the driller?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Botha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one drills Botha's stope but Botha, and he only works days. The miners look at each other knowingly and return to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rasputin, bloodied, his hands ripped apart by the stones, his chest torn by the rough timbers, labors on, Herculean.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: buried.   He hears movement above, faint but perceptible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strangled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help.   Help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rasputin sends another bucket up. He stands, his chest heaving. He hears something. He drops his ear to the floor. He hears the FAINTEST SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: He starts tearing away at the rock, doubling his effort.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: almost unconscious, hearing Rasputin's voice.   He breaks into the smallest of smiles and passes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pk sits in the hospital bed, battered but otherwise in good shape. Rasputin sits in a wheelchair by his bed- side, his hands and chest bandaged, pondering the chess- board between them. Jocko enters. JOCKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look at ya now, boyo. Up and at 'em in no time. And rich as a fuckin' lord. He tosses a fat wad of cash on PK's bed. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this? JOCKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your ticket to ride. Two hundred quid at fourteen to one. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I didn't make it.   I'm a month short. JOCKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not according to managment. They cashed you out at twelve months for eleven worked. Last thirty days was bonus. And until someone shows me a calendar reads different, twelve months and a year are one and the same kind of thing. And the bet was for a year. So get yourself mended and get your ass out of here. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's someone I have to see first. Jocko grows uncomfortable. JOCKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to go pressin' it for? You're rich, lad. You're whole. Why do you want to go pressin' it? PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I want to know. JOCKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what?   That the man has

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: blasted so much gelignite he's permanently deranged in the attic? That even the other drillers leave the bar when the man drinks, so crazed does he get. All right. He tried to kill you. But he didn't. You're alive is all that matters. Do us all a favor, boyo. Get out of here. Get on a train and don't come back. We've no liking to be burying someone we're all so fond of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No worries. The luckier you are, the longer you last. The longer you last, the luckier you are. Rasputin moves a chesspiece and bellows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checkmate!   Checkmate! He is ecstatic, bubbling with his joy.    Laughter springs from him. Jocko and PK trade a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an end to everything, boyo. Even luck. Jocko exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK walks to the seamy metal gate dressed, healed. Rasputin, his hands still bandaged, walks alongside of him. Rasputin is concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I guess this is goodbye, my friend. I'll never forget you. Rasputin speaks urgently in Russian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK. Botha.   Nyet, nyet.   Nyet, Botha. PK does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care, my friend. He grasps Rasputin's bandaged hand to shake it. Rasputin takes him around in a huge bear hug, smothering him. Pk survives, a bit rumpled. He smiles at Rasputin and exits. As he walks away,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK.   Botha.   Nyet. Nyet.    PK. PK turns the corner and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK walks through the huts of the drillers, massive to a man. Most of them are coming off shift. Some of them rub their temples, trying to soothe the pain of the powder. PK comes to one hut.     He knocks.   No answer.   He kno again. A DRILLER comes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who you lookin' for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Botha. The driller from stope number five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't disturb him. There's a reason he's there and we're here. The Driller enters his hut.     PK absorbs the warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three BARTENDERS stand outside along with a dozen other customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK.   You're not going to go in,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ja?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Botha the driller in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja. Always we give him one hour alone before we open. You don't know this because you work at night, but it is the rule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja.   In one hour it is pffft. He motions a man falling on his face. PK regards them for a moment and then enters the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the murky light one hulking figure sits at the bar, drinking shot after shot of whiskey. PK enters and walks across the room to the massive man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Botha? Botha does not turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm PK.   I worked your grizzly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you try to kill me? Botha turns slowly to reveal his face, swollen with anger and drink. He tears the short sleeve off his left arm, revealing a crudely tattooed swastika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I missed the first time, rooinek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaapie Botha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Botha rises drunkenly.     PK backs up. BOTHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember, rooinek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Botha.     It was thirteen years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because    of you they expelled me. Because    of you my father beat me. Threw me    out from the farm. Because    of you. He throws back another drink and rushes PK with a roar. PK sidesteps and heads for the door. Botha gets there first and bolts it. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Botha. We've made a lot of money working together. Let the past be the past. BOTHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ruined the country, all you rooineks. You come and ruin the country. He rushes PK again.     Again PK sidesteps. PK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Jaapie Botha. It's hate ruining the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaah. He swings at PK.     PK ducks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boer hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our country. At that moment the powder headache strikes. Botha bellows, grabbing his head staggering backward. PK runs for the door. As he reaches it a table slams against it, thrown halfway across the room by a powder-mad Botha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK jumps out of the way at the last minute. Men's faces begin to appear at the iron-meshed windows. People start to bang at the door. PK, realizing there is no talking to Botha now, does his best to stay out of the charging giant's way. Botha charges him. PK sidesteps and hits him with a left hook. The punch has no effect. Botha swings out wildly. PK easily dances away. Botha picks up another table and heaves it at PK. PK jumps to avoid it, but trips on an overturned stool. He goes down. The miners outside, crowding three deep, yell and shout. People start to make bets. Botha charges PK as PK scrambles up. Botha swings. The blow glances off PK's shoulder and sends him flying, spinning over a table. Botha leaps at PK, driving him into the wall. PK grimaces, sagging. Botha picks him up and starts to squeeze him to death in his massive arms. PK, his hands free, starts to pound on Botha's ears with his palms. Botha screams as the powder head- ache accelerates through the top of his skull. He drops PK. PK rolls away and swings a stool at Botha's midsection. Botha is driven back. PK goes to swing the stool again. Botha catches it as if it were made of balsa. He rips it out of PK's hand and flings it back at him, charging behind it. PK goes topping end over end. Botha gets a hand on him and lifts him from behind. He flings PK over the bar. PK hits the floor, stunned. Botha pulls at the bar trying to get at PK. He rocks the bar and rocks the bar as PK is trying to regain his bearings. Finally, with one tremendous rip, the bar comes away from its bolting. Botha pulls it aside. PK rises just as Botha moves in. PK hits him three solid shots to the stomach but Botha hardly feels them. He grabs PK and starts to squeeze him again. Face to face, Botha's crazed eyes watch the life fade from PK's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PK's eyes going blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: diving off a waterfall into the turbulent water below.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHA
dialogues.text: squeezing harder, breaking PK's concentration.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: swimming, exhausted, climbs on a rock, one more in front of him. He dives into the water again.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The crowd yells and screams as Botha squeezes harder. Odds are called out. Blood starts to trickle from PK's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead.   He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: as he swims to the last stone. He reaches it and struggles on top. He stands on the stone, trimphant.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHA
dialogues.text: squeezing again, bellowing. PK opens his eyes, draws his   head back, and butts Botha in the face. Botha's    nose shatters. The grip slackens a bit. PK hits him    in the face again. Botha drops PK to the floor as he   screams at the unbelievable pain. Blood pours from his    nose.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: catches his breath and is on Botha. He throws three hard punches to his face. Enraged, Botha howls and swings at PK. PK goes underneath his arm and hooks three times into the ribs. Botha grunts, hurt. He swings again with the other hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First with the head, then with the heart. Little defeat big when little is smart.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: pounds into Botha's ribs under another wild swinging punch by the giant. Botha shouts and keeps advancing, swinging. PK backs up, peppering him, leading him forward. Left-right. He punishes Botha for each punch the big man throws, but always backing up. Botha, half blind, spitting blood follows. The crowd screams for him to move side to side.   The betting changes fast and furious. PK glances over his  shoulder to the cement wall behind him. He takes two   more steps and then fires two jabs at Botha's face and  then stands stock still. Wild with anger, Botha throws  a huge right hand to PK's head.

dialogues.speaker: CLUB
dialogues.text: coming down on Maria's head.

dialogues.speaker: PK
dialogues.text: At the last moment PK sidesteps. Botha's hand    smashes into the cement wall. His hand shatters into    a hundred pieces. The pain is so immense he is rendered    helpless PK doesn't waste a second. He starts banging    away at Botha with hard, fast combinations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to see the wages of hate? Botha feels the punches.   He steps back, faltering. PK pursues him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.   Here is what hate gets you. PK hammers away, punching with each word, harder and faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For my chicken. For Geel Piet. For Doc. For Mandoma. For Maria. Botha is out on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Africa. PK unleashes a final pjnch -- the hardest one he ever threw. It catches Botha square in the jaw. Botha goes over onto his back like a tree falling. The crowd outside screams and yells with delight.     Mon changes hands. PK collects himself and steps over Botha.   He unbolts the door and steps outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd goes silent as PK emerges. The crowd parts. PK, looking neither right nor left, begins to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew as I walked out of the mines, out of Africa, that I wasn't fleeing. That one day I would return. Inkosi Inkosikasi was right. I was a man for all Africa. Bound to her by my spirit. Bound by my dreams. And Africa had taught me the lesson I would take out into the world and one day bring back. Great changes can come from the power of many. But only when the many join together and create what is invincible. The Power of One. ZOOM OUT as PK continues walking out of the camp and toward tomorrow.
